Review Design, preparation, application of advanced array structured materials and their action mechanism analyses for high performance lithium-sulfur batteries Nanping Deng a Xiaofan Feng a Yongbing Jin a Zhaozhao Peng a Yang Feng b Ying Tian a Yong Liu a ⁎ Lu Gao a ⁎ Weimin Kang a ⁎ Bowen Cheng a a State Key Laboratory of Separation Membranes and Membrane Processes/National Center for International Joint Research on Separation Membranes, School of Textile Science and Engineering, Tiangong University, Tianjin 300387, China State Key Laboratory of Separation Membranes and Membrane Processes/National Center for International Joint Research on Separation Membranes School of Textile Science and Engineering Tiangong University Tianjin 300387 China State Key Laboratory of Separation Membranes and Membrane Processes/National Center for International Joint Research on Separation Membranes, School of Textile Science and Engineering, Tiangong University, Tianjin 300387, China b Key Laboratory of Advanced Energy Materials Chemistry (Ministry of Education), Nankai University, Tianjin 300071, China Key Laboratory of Advanced Energy Materials Chemistry (Ministry of Education), Nankai University Tianjin 300071 China Key Laboratory of Advanced Energy Materials Chemistry (Ministry of Education), Nankai University, Tianjin 300071, China ⁎ Corresponding authors. Graphical abstracts The material preparation, synergistic design, and mechanism of action functional advantages of array structures for LSBs are reviewed, and the possible development strategies based on array structured materials for LSBs are summarized. Lithium-sulfur battery (LSB) has brought much attention and concern because of high theoretical specific capacity and energy density as one of main competitors for next-generation energy storage systems. The widely commercial application and development of LSB is mainly hindered by serious “shuttle effect” of lithium polysulfides (LiPSs), slow reaction kinetics, notorious lithium dendrites, etc. In various structures of LSB materials, array structured materials, possessing the composition of ordered micro units with the same or similar characteristics of each unit, present excellent application potential for various secondary cells due to some merits such as immobilization of active substances, high specific surface area, appropriate pore sizes, easy modification of functional material surface, accommodated huge volume change, enough facilitated transportation for electrons/lithium ions, and special functional groups strongly adsorbing LiPSs. Thus many novel array structured materials are applied to battery for tackling thorny problems mentioned above. In this review, recent progresses and developments on array structured materials applied in LSBs including preparation ways, collaborative structural designs based on array structures, and action mechanism analyses in improving electrochemical performance and safety are summarized. Meanwhile, we also have detailed discussion for array structured materials in LSBs and constructed the structure-function relationships between array structured materials and battery performances. Lastly, some directions and prospects about preparation ways, functional modifications, and practical applications of array structured materials in LSBs are generalized. We hope the review can attract more researchers' attention and bring more studying on array structured materials for other secondary batteries including LSB. Keywords Array structured materials Preparation methods and structural designs Action mechanism analyses Advanced Li-S batteries Excellent electrochemical performances and safety 1 Introduction With fast development and wide application of energy storage systems such as mobile electronic devices, electric vehicle energy supply, and large-scale grid renewable energy, it is rather important to vigorously develop the energy storage industry with high energy density and excellent safety [1–3]. In various energy systems, secondary batteries are viewed as one of the promising candidates for next-generation electrochemical energy storage devices in a variety of energy systems due to many beneficial attributes, including low environmental pollution [4,5], excellent safety [6], exceptional energy density, etc. [7,8]. Among various novel secondary batteries, lithium-sulfur battery (LSB) has high theoretical specific capacity (1675 mA h g−1) and admirable specific energy density (2600 W h kg−1), making it one of the most promising next-generation battery systems with high specific energy [9–11]. LSB is a particular type of battery system which uses lithium or lithium-containing storage materials as the anode and elemental sulfur or sulfur compounds as the cathode. It also has the ability to realize the mutual conversion of electrical and chemical energy based on the fracture/generation of sulfur-sulfur bonds as shown in Fig. 1 (a and b). Meanwhile, elemental sulfur also has some advantages of rich storage, low cost, and environmental friendliness. Therefore, LSB has broad application prospects in novel fields such as energy vehicles, unmanned aircraft, and other areas of electronic products [12–14]. Although LSB also has presented many merits, some headache shortcomings still significantly hinder fast commercialization process of LSB. These thorny problems mainly include some issues as following. (1) The inherent electronic insulation of elemental sulfur and low-order lithium polysulfides (LiPSs) such as Li2S2 and Li2S lead to slow kinetics of redox reaction during cycle. Meanwhile, the sluggish electron and low ion conduction rates of active materials also lead to voltage platform to cause serious polarization phenomenon, lowing actual energy density of LSB [15]. (2) The notorious “shuttle effect” of LiPSs dissolved in liquid electrolyte leads to active materials reduced and formed the dissolved LiPSs, which can react with metal lithium to form insoluble LiPSs covering the lithium surface, blocking fast transmission of Li+ [16]. (3) The volumetric change is as high as about 80% due to large density difference between the initial materials and the generated products, which can easily bring structural damage of electrode and lead to serious capacity fading [17]. (4) The terrible lithium dendrites in LSB still present the annoying growth ability, which is one of the main obstacles to the rapid development of LSB. Lithium is easy to have unexpected chemical reaction with the dissolved LiPSs caused by their “shuttle effect”, which makes the insulating Li2S2/Li2S passivation layer be formed from their reactions between them, bringing serious corrosion of metal lithium and irreversible loss of active materials. And the lithium dendrites also can pierce separator or electrolyte, causing a short circuit between electrodes [18]. All of these shortcomings would reduce electrochemical stability and significantly lower the electrochemical performance of LSB, leading to short cycle life, low Coulombic efficiency, and rapid discharge capacity fading. For effectively solving the above-mentioned problems, many strategies have been applied in the system composition of LSB to reduce these disadvantages, which mainly include the development of some novel materials even their modification and additional structural designs for further improving electrochemical performance and safety of LSB [19–22]. In many structural designs, array structured materials such as rod arrays, wire arrays, wall arrays, tube arrays, and their composite tube arrays also can obtain much attention for energy storage system including LSB. These ingeniously designed structures have unique merits in settling the main problems of LSB. The main advantages of array structural materials used in LSB are as follows. (1) The functional material of array structure generally has a large specific surface area, which is conducive to provide many loading sites for elemental sulfur and endow the exposure of the electrode or separator surface in the liquid electrolyte, which will effectively improve the lithium-ion transport and charge transfer [23]. This structure is also conducive to the rapid transmission of electrolyte, which will improve the electrochemical performance of battery in the poor electrolyte. (2) The gap between the sub-units in the array structured material can buffer huge volume expansion during cycle, thus effectively preventing the electrode structure from serious collapse and release the accumulation of stress and strain preventing material from cracking like the traditional compact film [24]. (3) The sub-units in the array structured material can be further designed as a composite array electrode with multi-function or multistage structure (such as porous or multistage) as a matrix, and the advantages of each component on the sub-units can be used cooperatively at the same time, which can further improve the performance of electrode or separator for LSBs [25]. (4) Immobilization of active substances in array structural materials can not only make the active substances as uniform, but also greatly reduce the loss of active substances and ultimately improve the utilization of active substances [26]. (5) Various materials of array structure can not only be designed with appropriate pore size to reduce “shuttle effect” of LiPSs through physical confinement method, but also be convenient for materials modification to chemically adsorb LiPSs and catalyze the conversion of LiPSs, which will effectively inhibit “shuttle effect” of LiPSs, which will significantly improve cell performance [27]. In addition, the integrated application of array structured materials and their supplementary multifunctional elements in LSBs also will bring about more admirable results. Meanwhile, some advantages also endow these array structured materials with novel chemical properties, which can lead to more opportunities for designing and conducting array structured materials with more evenly distributed lithium affinity active sites based on material modifications and structure designs [28]. And some researchers also have come up with the feasible viewpoints of combining array structured materials with other additional structure designs including various dimensional structures combining the other multi-functional materials to obtain array structure based composites, and summing up the cooperative effects of advantages and effectively make up for the disadvantages of both, leading to more outstanding electrochemical performances and safety for LSBs [29]. Nowadays, some array structured materials with innovative functionalities and other extra structures have been invented, conducted and used in LSB for further improving the electrochemical performances and safety of LSB [30,31]. Meanwhile, the experiment researches and patents about array structure applied in LSB present a momentum of fast growth and realize great progresses year by year on the whole as shown in Fig. 1(c). In recent years, a number of reviews have mentioned the application of array structure materials in LSBs. For example, Dong et al. [32] summarized the design of array structures in cathode materials by elaborating on the researching progresses of high-performance cathode materials of LSBs. Guo et al. [33] reviewed the array materials for binder-free electrodes including some by summarizing a binder-free electrode architecture design for LSBs. In addition, Ren et al. [34] partially noted the advantages of the array structures and outlined the multifunctional advantages and typical synthesis strategies for LSBs using array structure electrodes. However, there have been few discussions and explanations on functional designs and changes, including action mechanisms analyses, for array structured materials for LSB. Furthermore, there is no individual and complete overview of array structured materials for LSBs. In this review, its main aim is to bridge the gap and broaden the potential applications of array structured materials in LSBs. Based on these researches and the corresponding discussions, we will provide an in-depth analysis and evaluation of advanced array structured materials, their production methods, collaborative structural designs based the array structure for LSBs in this review. As well as being shown and discussed in detail in the review, their related morphological designs and associated action mechanisms of array structured materials in enhancing electrochemical performances and safeties for LSBs are also discussed. Then we also have introduced the corresponding electrochemical performances or safeties for LSBs and built the structure-function correlations between these array structured materials and various performances of LSBs. Last but not least, some opinions and proposals on researches and development trends of array structured materials for LSB in the future are also provided. We expect that the review can will attract the attention of researchers and lead to greater study on array structured materials for different secondary batteries based on the structural design principles and related theories of electrodes and separators. 2 Preparation ways, morphology designs and function mechanisms of array structured materials 2.1 Preparation ways of array structured materials Array structured materials are functional materials including special structures, which are same or similar to some sub-units uniformly grown on a plane (these sub-units mainly include wires, rods, tubes, ribbons, sheets, walls, flakes, and their combination forms). The preparation ways of array structured materials have been classified into the five types listed below: (1) hydrothermal way; (2) hot solvent method; (3) chemical vapor deposition (CVD); (4) electrodeposition method; (5) template method as presented in Fig. 2 . Additionally, integrating the aforementioned preparatory techniques will result in even better outcomes, which will lead to an increase in the number of roles that combine many functions [35,36]. Based on these preparation methods and theories, many multi-functional materials with array structure can be created by combining them with other additional structural designs and post-treatments. The results in array structured materials with enough activated sites, a controllable and multi-scale pore structure, and an appropriate array size and distribution, and their formed compounds with other merits. Finally, array structured materials can be widely applied for LSBs to evaluate cell performances. Thus the detailed introductions based on various preparation methods, including their advantages and disadvantages, will be provided. 2.1.1 Hydrothermal method In the process, water generally is acted as the medium in the reaction process to dissolve inorganic salt ions for obtaining the final array structured materials. When compared with other preparation techniques, the materials by the hydrothermal approach for array structured materials has many advantages such as comparatively small size of particles, uniform dispersion, few particulate aggregation, inexpensive raw materials, ease of obtaining suitable stoichiometry and crystal shape, reasonable gap, etc. [37]. However, at present, the hydrothermal method for obtaining array structured materials also has some disadvantages more or less: The reaction period is too long, the reaction process is carried out in a closed system, the reaction process cannot be seen in real time, which will bring some difficulties for the rapid commercialization of array structured materials using the way [38]. Meanwhile, the hydrothermal method for preparing non-oxide is still rare, especially its strict reaction conditions. All in all, in the future, the modified version of “hydraulic method” or the combination of hydrothermal method with other methods will need to be updated to obtain array structured materials with better performances for LSB. 2.1.2 Hot solvent method However, not all materials are suitable to be prepared by hydrothermal method. Some materials are difficult or even impossible to be synthesized in aqueous solution due to their easy oxidation and hydrolysis. It is necessary to replace the water in hydrothermal method with some corresponding organic solvents, which is commonly known as “thermal solvent method”. The preparation process of this method is relatively simple, and its preparation cost is also comparatively cheap. It can manage crystal nucleation and growth of crystal by varying the reaction time and strictly controlling the temperature. The merits of preparation way mainly include as follow. (a) The reaction in some organic solvents can inhibit the oxidation process of the products or the pollution of oxygen in water environment. (b) The application of non-aqueous solvents has greatly expanded the range of raw materials which is not available for the above-mentioned solvothermal reaction such as fluorides, nitrides, sulfur compounds, etc. Meanwhile, the unique physical and chemical properties of non-aqueous solvents under the sub-critical or supercritical conditions expand the range of target products. (c) Due to low boiling point of organic solvents, they can reach a higher pressure than the above-mentioned hydrothermal synthesis, which is conducive for the crystallization of products. (d) Due to low reaction temperature, the structural units in the reactant can be retained in the product without being damaged, which will bring more advantages to its industrialization process. Meanwhile, the organic solvent functional groups can react with the reactant or product to generate some novel materials with potential applications in catalysis and energy storage [39–41]. In general, the shortcomings of this method are the same as those of the hydrothermal method described above. 2.1.3 Chemical vapor deposition Apart from above two synthesis methods to prepare array structured materials, it is also of great significance to use chemical vapor deposition method to prepare some functional materials with array structure. CVD means that even under high temperature, reactants are transferred to the solid surface in the form of gas and react with it to produce new solid substances. CVD is also quite effective for the preparation of transition metal-based sulfides, selenides, and phosphides. In the specific preparation process, because these chemical products are easy to be oxidized in the air, it is necessary to inject inert gas for well protection of them during the preparation process. Due to its advantages of a straightforward operating procedure and a significantly reduced incidence of hard agglomeration during liquid phase synthesis, CVD has been used to prepare some array structured materials. This technique is particularly crucial for the preparation of array structured transition metal compounds. In particular, functional materials with array structure prepared by CVD also have a complete morphology, and the way also can effectively control the size and relatively accurate morphologies of the reaction products by regulating the feed ratio of reactants, reaction temperature, heating rate and reaction time, making them widely used in electrode materials [42–45]. However, array structured materials prepared by this method still have some disadvantages. (a) The deposition rate is not very high, and generally the rate is several to several hundred nm per minute. (b) Under some practical working conditions, the reaction source and the leftover from the reaction are likely to be flammable, explosive or toxic, which will lead to the requirement to take effective measures to prevent its pollution to the environment. In addition, for preparation equipment, this method often requires good corrosion resistance, which also leads to a significant increase in its preparation cost. (c) The applied CVD method is difficult to prepare materials with small size array structure. 2.1.4 Electrodeposition method The “electrodeposition method” refers to the process which metal ions in liquid electrolyte are reduced and recrystallized under certain current or voltage conditions, and various metal compounds also can be generated on the based materials. The difficulty of reaction of substances prepared by the electrodeposition method is often closely related to the physical or chemical properties of metal ions to be deposited. In addition, temperature, concentration, pH, current, and voltage of electrolyte in the reaction process all have large impact on the electrodeposition procedure. The electrochemical method is widely used to synthesize transition metal compounds with array structure due to its relatively simple device, safe environment and comparatively easy to control the ideal thickness. In the process of electrodeposition, some researchers can control the nucleation and growth of crystals by setting various parameters in the electrodeposition process, which will enable the preparation of array structured materials combining additional structures. All of these will also affect the morphologies and structures of electrode materials. On the whole, the preparation of electrode materials with the array structure by using the method is a relatively simple, efficient, accurate and low-cost method [46–49]. However, the electrodeposition method for preparing array structured materials also has many defects. (1) The deposited particle size by the electrodeposition method is relatively large and the final particle size is also uneven. (2) The precipitation time may be longer than that of other methods for array structured materials, which will make it difficult to ensure the thickness uniformity of electrodeposited film. (3) The preparation way is also relatively difficult to strictly control the time and speed of electrodeposition. (4) The electrodeposition method is easy to produce concentration polarization and produced gas during the process, which will affect the quality of the electrodeposited coating for these array-structured materials. 2.1.5 Template method The template approach is classified into two categories: hard and soft template method. The hard template approach primarily employs prefabricated rigid templates such as anodic alumina template, microporous, mesoporous molecular sieve, mesoporous zeolite, porous polycarbonate film, porous silicon, metal template, etc. for designing the predetermined structure. The soft template method is mainly based on the mesoporous phase of surfactant. Through using rod micelles and microemulsions as templates, it also can guide the growth of nanomaterials in its pores for obtaining the designed structural materials. Various materials synthesized by hard and soft template method usually have the following advantages. (1) Various materials synthesized by the template method have considerable flexibility. (2) Different materials prepared by template method can reduce their agglomeration effect. (3) They can effectively control the dimension and morphology of the array structured materials. (4) The applied equipment is relatively simple and the preparation conditions are relatively mild. The hard template is mainly a static channel, and the prepared material can only enter the channel from the opening, whereas the soft template is primarily a dynamically balanced cavity, with the obtained material only diffusing in and out through the hollow wall [50–53]. The preparation of array structured materials by template synthesis method is the process of the applied materials with nano-structure, shape easy to synthesize and control, affordable and simple to obtain as templates, depositing pertinent materials into holes or surfaces with certain shape templates by the chemical or physical processes, and removing templates in the later stage, so as to obtain array structured materials with template standard morphology and size. The result makes the array structured materials by the hard and soft template method have the following advantages when applied to LSBs. (1) Array structure can be directly grown on the conductive substrate, which can reduce the contact resistance of the array structured materials, realizing the requirements of rapid charge transfer. (2) Through using this method, the gap between the array structured materials can be controlled accurately, which can not only provide sufficient and convenient transmission channels for mass transfer of electrolyte, but also successfully increase the materials' particular area of the surface, thereby raising the number of active sites. (3) Array structured materials created using the template method particularly the hard template, also exhibit excellent stability, which can provide a strong guarantee for long-term and sustainable redox reaction of LSBs. However, these two template methods usually also have some disadvantages. For example, the structural stability of the materials generated using the soft template is frequently weak, resulting in low efficiency of the array structured materials created using the soft template. And the morphology of the materials by hard template usually changes less, resulting in a few varieties of preparation, which is not conducive to design and prepare diversified array structured materials. All in all, the detailed flowchart outlining the relevant synthesis methods and a comparison of those different methods together are presented in Fig. S1. This figure will provide us with further rational design and preparation of array structured materials in the future, and apply them to build a solid foundation in LSBs. 2.2 Design of different morphologies with array structured materials If the relevant preparation ways and their electrochemical and safety performances for array structured materials with multi-functional roles are not taken into account, these array structured materials mainly can be categorized as various groups according to the shapes of the materials attached to the corresponding templates, which mainly can be classified as rod arrays, wire arrays, wall arrays, tube arrays, composited tube arrays and their comprehensive combination. In fact, we also can mainly divide the composite materials on the based films into 0D, 1D, 2D, and 3D based array structured materials according to different dimensions of additional or constituent materials. Some array structured materials also have fantastically rich chemical compositions for improving electrochemical performances of LSBs. These components, which contain their respective functional roles, can better achieve the multi-functional modification ways of various goals of materials for entire battery system when they are chosen and used as main materials with array structure [54,55]. For additional or constituent materials with various dimensions combining the main-designed array structured materials, they also have additional advantages in application of LSBs. When 0D materials are applied in LSBs, they have the characteristics of simple synthesis, low cost, high efficiency and no self-absorption, and they are easy to achieve functional treatments on the surface of materials, so that they can be stably dispersed in common solvents, meeting the requirements of low-cost processing of materials. These benefits enable its application in LSBs to show effective adsorption of LiPSs while also greatly improving the catalytic performance of functional materials. Meanwhile, 1D materials have also been frequently utilized in LSBs because of their controllable preparation, high specific surface properties, long-range ordered structure convenient for rapid conduction of electrons or Li+, high strength, excellent hardness, well wear resistance, good corrosion resistance, strong oxidation resistance, outstanding creep resistance, high thermal conductivity and other merits [56–58]. These advantages will make it be significantly helpful for the quick transfer of Li+ in electrodes or in separators, which will also effectively suppressing “shuttle effect” of LiPSs and the quick switching between reactants throughout cycle processes. Due to their ultra-thin conductive structure, high electrolytic stability, shape adjustable preparation, huge specific surface area, and completely used properties of accessible reaction sites on active chemicals, 2D materials have been widely used in LSBs. All of these advantages will dramatically reduce “shuttle effect” of LiPSs and provide more reaction catalytic active sites, both of which would enhance LSBs' the electrochemical performance [59–61]. Among them, 3D materials have become an important part of novel functional materials due to their structural diversities and performance advantages, and various 3D materials have been applied in various fields especially in energy battery system. 3D materials often have relatively complex micro-morphology, which usually shows the benefits of combination of 1D and 2D materials. Therefore, the materials using 3D materials also can combine and further amplify the positive properties of 1D and 2D materials, thus endowing materials with potential applications in LSBs through rapidly transmitting electrons or Li+, inhibiting the LiPSs shuttling or lithium dendrites and speeding up the reaction kinetics [62–64]. The detailed comparisons of the advantages and disadvantages of four types of array-structure materials: 0D, 1D, 2D, and 3D are presented in Fig. S2. The functional materials, such as array structures, typically have large specific surface areas, strong ability to buffer huge volume expansion, immobilization role of active substances in array structural materials, appropriate pore size to reduce LiPSs shuttling through physical confinement, reasonable modificas can combine the benefits of these two or more functional materials to produce an overall effect that is superior to that of each component alone, providing more opportunities for improving its physical and chemical properties in LSBs to chemically adsorb LiPSs and excellent catalytic conversion of LiPSs as shown in Fig. 2. This makes an important contribution to the development of new functional materials. As a result, the composite materials can be created by constructing array structure. 2.3 Mechanisms of array-structured materials for LSBs As illustrated in Fig. 3 , action mechanism analyses of array structured materials for LSBs are as follows: the facilitated migration of electrons and lithium ions, the effectively suppressed “shuttle effect” of LiPSs on the basis of the physical confinement, chemical adsorption especially their combinations, the reduced lithium dendrites, quick catalysis and conversion. Additionally, the key compositions of array structured materials are also depicted in the figure. Following that will be a thorough discussion of array structured materials for LSBs. 2.3.1 Facilitated transmission of electrons and lithium ions The fast transfer of electrons and Li+ is critical in both liquid and solid state batteries for lithium batteries [65]. Hence, the increased conductivity of Li+ is a crucial component of array structured materials used to promote the improvement of the electrochemical performance of LSBs. Among many multi-functional materials with unique structures enhancing the rapid transmission of Li+, some array structured materials have widely been methodically designed and perfectly produced for various secondary batteries especially LSBs. The fundamental reason is that the array structured materials usually have enough active sites, high specific surface area, outstanding stability, long-range ordered transport with sufficient cavity structures and reasonable accommodation. Such characteristics are conducive to accelerating the rapid diffusion of Li+ and electrons on the basis of an exceptionally stable structure. In addition, some researchers have demonstrated new array structural materials, based on the original array structural materials, through careful design and multifunctional modification, such as chemical doping treatment of array structural materials, structural design of array structural materials, in-situ growth and preparation of multifunctional materials or composite of array structural materials, etc., to obtain a close contact with other battery components and reduce the interface resistance. Meanwhile, the array structured materials also can effectively absorb and preserve much liquid electrolyte, including abundant Li+ during the redox process of LSBs. Moreover, there are also array structured materials that can be applied as primary hosts and to accommodate large volume change of electrodes which can greatly absorb and conveniently conducted Li+. As an illustration, Xia et al. [66] carefully planned and rationally created highly porous carbon fiber/vanadium nitride arrays for LSBs using a simple chemical etching technique combined with a solvothermal-supercritical fluid method to contain sulfur in an integrated composite support. More active elemental sulfur can be confined in the prepared porous carbon fiber/vanadium nitride array scaffold, and the porous carbon fiber/vanadium nitride array/elemental sulfur integrated electrode can realize the dual blocking effect of “physical confinement and chemical absorption” for lithium-ion batteries. What's more, the porous carbon fiber/vanadium nitride array with a highly porous structure can also provide a large holding space for the active sulfur and possess cross-linked labyrinth channels to physically immobilize the lithium-ion battery during cycling. Thus the “shuttle effect” of the batteries can be effectively suppressed. The combination of carbon materials with excellent conductivity and light weight and reasonable array structure materials also helps to conduct electrons conveniently, along with effectively accelerates the transmission of lithium ions during cycling process. Li+ from lithium metal and an abundance of lithium ions during the redox process can easily enter into the array structure materials, greatly decreasing the diffusion resistance and promoting the rapid diffusion and transport of Li+. 2.3.2 Chemical adsorption, physical confinement and their combinations It is well known that LSB can realize high discharge capacity through cascading redox reaction [67]. Unfortunately, many high-order LiPSs formed in cycle processes can shuttle back and forth between electrodes of LSB based on the cascade-by-cascade reaction process [68]. Based on the principles of elaborate structural design and rational modification, the electrochemical performance and safety of LSBs have been significantly improved by modifying and functionalizing the battery electrodes or separators, but the rapid development of LSBs is still hampered based on the well-known and unavoidable “shuttling effect” of LiPSs and the slow reaction kinetics [69]. At the early development stage of LSBs, some scholars took the perspective of “physical confinement” to effectively prevent the shuttling effect of LiPSs by “surrounding” and “blocking” the LiPSs [70]. Physical confinement serves to reduce the diffusion of LiPS by physically confining it in porous materials or by creating external physical barriers, including further narrowing the gap or pore size, such as the application of array-structured materials and specially designed porous structures [71]. Based on this, the loss of LSB active materials has indeed been significantly reduced and the electrochemical performance of LSBs has been improved to some extent. Firstly, the array structured materials have elaborately designed pores, which bring a good and stable structural skeleton and provide enough spaces for effectively storing much sulfur compound. Meanwhile, array structured materials can also be effective in accommodating large volume changes and effectively reducing the “shuttle effect” of Li batteries on the basis of physical constraints. Secondly, some appeared array structured materials containing some pores can also be applied to separators or interlayers of LSB, which can be considered as second layers or walls of encapsulating LiPSs, and can further suppress “shuttle effect” of LiPSs during the cycle processes. Thirdly, some array structured materials with more layers of pores (e.g., micropores or mesopores) can also could be designed and applied to further inhibit the “shuttle effect” of LiPSs. If a functional material is prepared with so few macroporous structures, it also negatively affects its ability to store more active materials. Therefore, the conflict between these two factors ought to be balanced when regulating the pore structure of various array structural materials used for LSBs. However, relying on a single physical constraint to effectively reduce the “shuttle effect” of LiPSs is still difficult to achieve and quite limited. Furthermore, some array structured carbon materials are un-polarized and it is very hard to constrain polarized LiPSs during cycle processes. Therefore, it is particularly important to design and prepare some polar multifunctional materials that potently inhibit LiPSs shuttling in combination with the effective chemistry of LiPSs. For example, Liu et al. devised and fabricated the electrocatalytic NiCo2O4 nanofiber arrays on carbon cloth for flexibly highly loaded LSBs. On the one hand, the polar affinity can enable NiCo2O4 to remarkably adsorb LiPSs and suppress LiPSs shuttling. On the other hand, the NiCo2O4 was a mixed-valence oxide with redox couples of Co3+ or Co2+ and Ni3+ or Ni2+, which was an excellent electrocatalyst to accelerate the transition reaction kinetics of LiPSs. In addition, the 1D nanostructures offer good electron conduction and Li+ diffusion paths, while contributing sufficient active sites for the fast conversion reaction of LiPSs. The 3D network created by interconnecting carbon cloth fibers could also mitigate the enormous volume shift of the sulfur-based cathode, especially under high loading conditions. Based on the above advantages, the array structure materials not only restrain the LiPSs based on physical adsorption, but also reduce their “shuttle effect” by adsorbing the LiPSs through the strong chemical interaction formed between the LiPSs and the polar NiCo2O4. As a result, the LSBs presented high reversible discharge capacity and excellent cycle stability as well [72]. In brief, the array structured materials with some doped polar materials have been shown to take an important role in greatly enhancing the chemisorption and improving the cycling stability of LiPSs. Thus, the combination of physical confinement and chemical adsorption can suppress the “shuttle effect” of LiPSs. However, especially in the mass production process, it is difficult to completely avoid the damage to the material structure during chemical modification, which may reduce or inhibit the physical confinement effect of LiPSs. Hence, how to balance the roles between the above-mentioned two factors is likewise a thorny problem which still requires to be carefully considered in the future researches. 2.3.3 Suppressing lithium dendrites The generation and formation of uneven lithium dendrites can appear upon direct application of pure commercial olefinic separators to LSBs [73]. This is primarily due to the fact that the obtained olefinic separators, which mainly consist of polyethylene, polypropylene or their composites, produce severe polarization and high interfacial impedance, based on the disadvantages of the inhomogeneous distribution about the charges and Li+ currents. Therefore, reducing the local current density and uniformly distributing the charge and Li+ are keys to improving the cycling properties of LSB by lowering the formations and growth of lithium dendrites. Meanwhile, lithium dendrite problem of LSBs can also be reduced through important ways such as electrolyte optimization, surface modification of metal lithium, functional separator design and preparation, the introduction of additional interlayers, or the application of novel collectors. For instance, Jin et al. produced the mixed-valent MOFs with isolated Ce(IV, III) arrays based on the susceptibility of Ce(III) formation under MOFs synthesis conditions to improve the separator of LSBs. The mixed-valence cerium MOFs can provide the efficient adsorption to LiPSs, fast redox conversion kinetics and facilitated Li+ transport rate. Finally the superior electrochemical properties can be achieved [74]. To sum up, formation and continued growth of the infamous lithium dendrites in LSBs assembled by applying array structural materials can be reduced or suppressed by using many methods to even out the Li+ current and charge distribution. All these benefits can lead to excellent electrochemical performance and admirable safety of LSBs. In addition, some researchers also have prepared array structural materials with certain functional properties to separators/interlayers of LSBs, which also can lower lithium dendrites to further improving the safety. 2.3.4 Fast catalysis and conversion With the aim of greatly reducing the shuttle effect in LiPSs, greatly increasing the availability of active materials, and significantly bettering the electrochemical performance of LSBs, many researchers have undertaken many researching works through a combination of physical confinement and chemical adsorption, thus the electrochemical performance of LSB has been improved [75,76]. However, up to now, there is still a slow electrochemical reaction kinetics problem which needs to be solved urgently [77,78]. The problem of slow response kinetics will become more and more serious if the area density of active materials in LSBs is appropriately increased or the application of additional intercalation layers is even further introduced [79,80]. The main reason is that the LSB is a step-by-step reaction process in the discharge reaction process, which is more complex than lithium insertion/removal mechanism for traditional lithium-ion battery [81,82]. Therefore, it is important to use some functional catalysts to improve the reaction kinetics of LSBs. According to the principle, some functional catalysts with sufficient reactive sites and small reaction energies have been widely applied to LSBs, which have gradually improved their reaction kinetics and thus significantly catalyzed and rapidly converted LiPSs [83,84]. Functional catalysts offer the advantages of excellent electronic conductivity, sufficient active sites and reduced chemical reaction energy barriers. They can function effectively even under high elemental sulfur loading of LSB and poor liquid electrolyte. For these functional catalysts, some functional materials with array structures can also be used as excellent electrocatalysts to improve electrochemical reactions, which are attributed to the fact that array-structured materials which can provide enough space to confine and further catalyze reactive substances [20]. Moreover, the array structured materials can accommodate large volume changes due to catalysis. During reduction, the primary role of these functional capacitors is to effectively accelerate the transformation of LiPSs to Li2S2 or Li2S insoluble in liquid electrolyte, which in turn reduces LiPS shutting. Due to the facilitation of reaction kinetics during the redox process, these functional catalysts also enable the rapid conversion of low-order Li2S2/Li2S to higher-order LiPSs and elemental sulfur. In addition, the introduction of array-structured compounds with special chemical groups could also improve the redox reaction. For example, Zhan et al. fabricated the P doped hierarchical porous carbon nano-sheet array based on the template method to modify the separator of LSBs [85]. A hierarchical porous phosphorus doped carbon nanosheet array microstructure may be produced by smoothly adjusting the copolymerization rate of formaldehyde, resorcinol, phytic acid and other compounds by modifying the amount of added phytic acid. The P doping can also introduce some surface flaws and enhance the polarity of the P doped hierarchical porous carbon nanosheet array, which prevented the unfavorable oxidation of LiPSs during redox processes and demonstrated a metal-like LiPSs anchoring effect by forming Li–P and S–P bonds. The LSBs employing the modified separator with the generated P doped hierarchical porous carbon nanosheet array demonstrated great electrochemical performance and safety. Certainly, some metal compounds with nanostructures, like array-structured metal sulfides, metal oxides, metal nitrides and metal phosphates, are also suitable for metal catalysts to accelerate the LSB reaction rate. Not only do the prepared catalysts favor the diffusion of Li+, but also their reaction conversions are improved due to sufficient “sulfiphilic” sites [86–88]. So far, several carbon-based materials [89], single-atom catalysts [90], MOFs [91] or COFs [92] and their derived or modified catalysts, hydrotalcite catalysts [93], boron nitride catalysts [94], catalysts of organic compounds [95], etc. are also designed and prepared for improving reaction kinetics during cycle. Meanwhile, these catalysts applied in LSB also present different dimensions in various structures, which these structure mainly includes 0D structured materials (ball, pellet, bead, particle, powder, etc.) [96], 1D structured materials (tube, fiber, wire, chains, belts, needles, whiskers, coaxial cables, etc.) [97], 2D structured materials (array, layer, sheet, etc.) [98], and 3D structured materials (bulk, box and so on) [99] in order to facilitate catalysis and rapid conversion. So that when multifunctional array structured materials are designed and prepared by some researchers, one has more opportunities to select suitable catalyst materials and integrate array structure with other structures. 3 Array structured materials for electrodes of LSBs Array structured materials, as highly oriented materials, have controllable size, easy to achieve doping and controllable degree of reaction, especially in nano-array materials, showing more excellent nano and quantum effects [100]. Especially, the prepared array structured carbon materials as the electrodes of LSB have many advantages such as reasonable buffer space, large specific surface area, and convenient lithium ion and electron transport channels [101–103]. Meanwhile, the reasonable gap space of array structured materials can also effectively solve the aggregation problem of active materials in cell cycle. More importantly, the materials including array structure can not only be prepared with appropriate pore size to decrease “shuttle effect” of lithium-ion batteries on the basis of physical constraints, but also be helpful for materials modification to chemically adsorb LiPSs and catalyze the transformation between LiPSs and elemental sulfur, which will greatly effectively suppress LiPSs shuttling, finally enhancing electrochemical performance [104,105]. 3.1 Array structured carbon materials The constant popularization and improvement of the preparation methods of the array structure materials will also endow them with more functionality and further improve the performance of LSBs. For cathode, elemental sulfur, which is the main material, has the fatal disadvantage of extremely low electronic conductivity. In recent years, a wide range of carbon materials as additives have received extensive attention in LSBs due to their merits such as high electronic conductivity, large specific surface area, excellent physical properties, outstanding chemical stability, easy modification, relatively low cost, etc. [106–108]. Nowadays, array structured carbon materials applied in LSBs mainly includes carbon nanotubes arrays, interconnected mesoporous carbon arrays, carbon nanorods arrays, carbon nanoflake arrays, carbon nanosphere arrays, carbon nanosheets arrays, carbon nanoflake arrays, carbon networks arrays, carbon quantum arrays, their combinations, graphene, and so on. As everyone knows, as a superior type of carbon material, carbon nanotubes (CNTs) have been investigated and applied cell system because of outstanding mechanical durability, excellent electrical conductivity, extremely stable chemical properties as well as easy modification [109,110]. When CNTs combining array structure are applied in the electrode of advanced LSBs, the cell can produce admirable effect. In the early period, Wang et al. [111], Zhang et al. [112], and Li et al. [113] designed and fabricated the disordered carbon nanotubes array, aligned carbon nanotube/sulfur composite and a binder-free vertically-aligned carbon nanotube/sulfur as sulfur hosts, respectively. For the former, elemental sulfur can be incorporated into the hollow core on the basis of the porous shell of carbon particles, and the liquid electrolyte access to the porous shell can be facilitated through the 2–4 nm-sized pores. As shown in Fig. 4 (a), based on the application of elemental sulfur vapor infusion, small molecules S6 or S2 at high temperature had strong ability to diffuse through the narrow pore pathway in the shell into a hollow core based on the CNTs array and change back to the more stable macromolecule S8. But the narrow pore sizes in the carbon shells based on carbon nanotube arrays are small, which can prevent the penetration of liquid electrolytes and effectively avoid dissolution of LiPSs. For the next two, the aligned CNTs can be acted as mutually connected conductive scaffolds to adapt to huge volume change of electrode. The ultra-high loading of elemental sulfur is due to the open, ordered and straight pore structure of the CNT scaffolds, which allows for uniform distribution of fine sulfur particles. While the solid carbon framework formed also serves as a fast channel for electron transfer, the neatly aligned, high aspect ratio and orderly packing of individual CNT micelles also produce a low conductive percolation threshold. Finally, the electrodes can be utilized for LSBs with the improved energy density. And some modified materials with array structured CNTs in the later stage have also been used in electrode materials. For further improving performance of CNTs with array structure for electrode of LSBs, some porous CNTs especially with hierarchical hole structure have been developed and prepared as cathode of advanced LSBs. The main reasons are that CNTs with hierarchical hole structure including micropore, mesopore, and macropore have their own advantages. Macropore is conducive to storing more active substances, which can improve the energy density of the battery. Mesopore, especially micropore, can effectively inhibit the LiPSs shuttle effect while ensuring the smooth transport of liquid electrolyte and lithium ions, thus dramatically improving the electrochemical performance of LSBs. And the ultra-thin thickness, admirable structural properties and excellent conductivity are also rather vital factors of microporous and mesoporous carbon [114,115]. Based on these reasons, various hierarchical CNTs have been widely produced and applied in cathode materials of LSBs. Hu et al. [116] and Pint et al. [117] prepared S-impregnated 3D hierarchical porous N-doped coordinated carbon nanotubes (HPNACNTs) arrays with well-directed one-dimensional conductive electronic pathways and site-selective gas-phase S-impregnated hierarchical carbon nanotubes arrays acting as sulfur host for LSBs, respectively. Thus, the assembled LSBs have excellent electrochemical properties. Meanwhile, the carbon network also has many advantages, such as outstanding electrical conductivity, admirable accessible surfaces, structural coherence with based materials and a favorable and stable structure with physical and chemical aspect. Wang et al. [118] and Peng et al. [119] prepared elemental sulfur nanocrystals confined in carbon nanotube network of carbon nanotubes and aligned layered nanostructured carbon hybrid cathodes for LSBs. For the former, the special structure formed can provide a conductive network, accommodate huge volume expansion, and effectively provide physical constraints for LiPSs. The array-structured sulfur-based composites can provide a more open environment that allows sufficient liquid electrolyte to penetrate and facilitate rapid Li+ transport. For the latter, the mesoporous carbon can be acted as sulfur electrode and reduced diffusion of LiPSs. And the formed aligned and laminated CNT network also can well confine the sulfur-absorbed mesoporous carbon particles, leading to fast channels for rapid electron transportation, thus reducing LiPSs migration and making the collapsible LSBs highly flexible as presented in Fig. 4(b). More importantly, the cathode also can significantly provide the cell good flexibility to keep itself deformations. This work was an efficient way to enhance the power supply system for flexible devices and brings encouraging results for its practical application. In addition, other dimensions of CNTs such as 3D, can also be utilized as electrode materials to further improve electrochemical performance of LSBs. As well known, 3D structured materials have many advantages such as high porosity, specific surface area, excellent long-range conductivity, sufficient active interfaces and strong physical constraints on sulfur compound. Notably, the highly porous structure can also form an interconnected 3D framework on the basis of the carbon matrix, which promotes the transfer of Li+, overcomes the problem of slow vertical ion conduction in some carbon materials with layered microstructures, and realizes the rapid transfer of ions within the electrodes to achieve efficient performance of sulfur electrochemistry. Thus, some 3D array structured materials have been widely prepared and utilized in LSBs [120]. As shown in Fig. 4(c), Yang et al. prepared the binder-free and self-supported two CNT skeletons with 3D porous structures including vertically aligned carbon nanotube array and 3D interconnected carbon nanotube sponge as sulfur host for LSB [121]. Vertically arranged CNT arrays can provide high-efficient channels for migration of the electrons and Li+, resulting in good cycle stability. Besides CNTs with array structure applied in LSBs, some other structured carbon materials such as carbon nanorods arrays, carbon nanoflake arrays, carbon nanoflake arrays, carbon nanosphere arrays also have been applied in LSBs. Carbon nanorod arrays have the following three advantages in the application of LSBs electrodes, which has attracted widespread attention of many researchers. (1) 1D carbon nanorods can provide a “high-speed channel” for electrons transport because of the few grain boundaries, and can carry out fast electrons or lithium ions transport in the vertical direction. (2) Carbon nanorods have a significantly greater specific surface area and can offer more active sites. (3) Its longitudinal shape of carbon nanorod is generally large and straight 1D cylindrical, and its cross section is designed to be polygonal and each nanorod is hollow, which can store enough elemental sulfur [122,123]. According to these merits, many scholars prepared various carbon nanorods arrays. Tu et al. fabricated independent sulfur cathodes combining with 3D carbon nanorods arrays as sulfur host as presented in Fig. 4(d) [124]. The materials with the array structured carbon nanorods can efficiently improve the electrical conductivity, increase the specific surface area and inhibit the diffusion of LiPSs into liquid electrolyte. These excellent properties may contribute to the commercialization process of LSBs. In conclusion, the performance of LSBs can be improved by further modifying the materials based on the array structure. Carbon nanoflake, due to its ultra-thin morphology, large specific surface area, and enough exposed active sites, can improve loading of active substances and provide convenient channels for the fast transport of electrons and Li+ when applied to cathode of LSBs, which also enables it to load efficient polar catalysts through using more modification methods [125]. In this way, the combined carbon material of this structure can effectively inhibit “shuttle effect” of LiPSs through the physical imprisonment and chemical adsorption. Xia et al. produced carbon nanoflake/sulfur arrays as the cathode of LSBs [126]. The interlinked carbon nanoflake arrays had a dual function, not only as a highly conductive substrate for storing elemental sulfur, but also as a barrier layer to inhibit “shuttle effect” of LiPSs. Nowadays, carbon sphere arrays have attracted attention, and their tunable pore size distribution, novel surface properties and sufficient pore capacity show great potential for applications. Many carbon sphere arrays including porous structure, yolk-shell structure, hollow structure and different biomimetic structure have been prepared for LSBs. The voids inside the carbon spheres not only offer enough space for storing elemental sulfur, but can also accommodate large volume changes. The shell walls also create physical constraints that inhibit “shuttle effect” of LiPSs. The shells of the carbon sphere arrays have large surface area and present effective pathways to transfer electrons and Li+ in cell electrodes [127,128]. For example, Guo et al. [129] and Biggs et al. [130] fabricated arrays of nitrogen hollow carbon spheres filled with porous carbon nanosheets (NHCS-PCS) and highly porous and mono-disperse N-doped carbon nanospheres array as sulfur hosts. Combining the array structure and other factors, the LSBs both presented good cyclic stability. Besides carbon nanosphere arrays, some additional structures combining the array structure also have been prepared for LSBs due to their extra functions, which can further improve the electrochemical performance and safety. For example, Shao et al. prepared the hollow carbon nanospheres with ultra-thin and ordered mesoporous shells based on the facile dual-template-assisted hydrothermal carbonization of eco-friendly, sustainable and inexpensive fructose as sulfur host [131]. The ordered concave nanopore arrays integrated into the balloon-like hollow carbon nanospheres with ultra-thin and ordered mesoporous shells can provide highly efficient diffusion of Li+ including the accessibility of liquid electrolyte and rapid electron transfer pathways including excellent active materials confinement. The spherical hollow nanosphere structure also can present large pore volume for sulfur deposition and reduce the stress deriving from the change in the sulfur species volume, which can guarantee high morphological stability. More importantly, the hierarchically ordered porous carbon shell with the proper content of oxygen functional groups also can further provide well confinement of soluble LiPSs, thereby mitigating their “shuttle effect” and improving cycling stability. Like the CNTs with 3D structure described above, carbon nanosphere arrays are also widely designed and prepared as materials with 3D structure to further improve the electrochemical performance of LSBs. Yin et al. fabricated 3D ordered bimodal mesoporous carbon through a surfactant-free rapid method using SiO2 nanosphere arrays as templates for LSBs as presented in Fig. 4(e) [132]. The highly periodic arrays of uniform large mesopores of ordered bimodal mesoporous carbon obtained from the accurate replication of SiO2 nanosphere array was rather facilitated to the accessibility of liquid electrolyte and electrons transfer. The formed mesopore walls including linked small mesopores in the ordered bimodal mesoporous carbon can be generated. And the SiO2 template also can restrict the shrinkage of phenolic resins and the small mesopores originating from the solvent removal can be maintained after calcination process. More importantly, small mesopores also can suppress migration and diffusion of LiPSs, thus realizing high electrochemical stability for LSBs. From the above introduction, we can see that the electrochemical performance and safety of battery have been improved by the careful design of the array structure and the application of the materials in LSBs. In addition, some researchers also integrated the respective advantages of the above various structures, and the performance of the battery can be further improved when the carbon materials with comprehensive array structure are applied in LSBs. Li et al. [133] and Zhu et al. [134] prepared the multi-leveled carbon nanoflake-nanosphere networks composed of nanoflake-nanospheres by the sacrificial ZnO nanoflake array template and the hydrothermal carbonization of glucose and dual functional, highly ordered and interconnected mesoporous carbon arrays for LSBs. In the front example, the multi-leveled carbon nanoflake-nanosphere networks as presented in Fig. 4(f) not only can be utilized as large-area host and backbone for sulfur forming an integrated composite electrode, but also can be served as multiple carbon blocking barriers including the nanoflake infrastructure and nanosphere superstructure to physically confine LiPSs at the area of cell cathode. In the behind example, the prepared interconnected mesoporous carbon arrays annealed at high temperature presented the enhanced electric conductivity due to the high graphitization, which further improved the electron conductivity of sulfur electrode and enhanced cycling performance. Carbon “quantum” dots are usually defined as small nanoparticles with different surface passivation ways. When carbon “quantum” dots are applied in LSBs system, they have some merits such as a sub-30 nm size, large specific surface area and enough surface functional sites, which can provide many active sites for LiPSs absorption and localization. Furthermore, 0D carbon “quantum” dots also can uniformly cover the target materials because of small size and outstanding dispersibility, thus providing strong localized chemical interactions with LiPSs during cycle process, thus maintaining enough active materials and additives. For example, Zhang et al. converted well-defined lignin into porous carbon and carbon quantum dots using an array of techniques for LSBs [135]. The affluent pores and channels of well-defined lignin into porous carbon can be easily penetrated by molten sulfur and liquid electrolyte to cathode. Meanwhile, the composite with “array” structure can accommodate huge volume change and suppress “shuttle effect” of LiPSs. Thus LSBs presented good electrochemical performance. Graphene is a material with a single-layer 2D honeycomb lattice structure based on closely packed carbon atoms with sp 2, which can enable the prepared graphene to have superior electrical, mechanical, optical, and other properties. When graphene is used as scaffolds for cathodes, the excellent electrical conductivity of graphene material can form an excellent conductive network within the sulfur electrode, achieving high utilization of the active material. In addition, the graphene framework can provide sufficient pore volume to store active materials and is highly fault-tolerant to adapt to huge volume changes of sulfur electrode during redox reaction. More importantly, the 3D interconnected hierarchical macroporous networks of graphene can hold the active materials and effectively inhibit the diffusion of LiPSs into the liquid electrolyte, thus facilitating the Li+ transfer during cycle and reducing the loss of active materials [136]. By way of example, Yang et al. fabricated the vertically aligned sulfur-graphene nanowalls, where sulfur nanoparticles were anchored between graphene layers and ordered graphene arrays were aligned perpendicularly to the substrate, enabling LSBs to achieve excellent performance [137]. Based on the structure of the composite, the perpendicularly aligned sulfur graphene nanowalls are quite favorable for rapid diffusion of Li+ and electrons. Meanwhile, the layered and porous structure is favorable to well adapt to huge volume change of electrode. Combining these advantages, LSBs have excellent reversible capacity, outstanding high-rate capability and well cycle-ability. In addition, adding some additional structures to the prepared material based on the array structure will further increase the electrochemical performance of the prepared materials. Hassoun et al. also fabricated 3D-array nanostructured graphene-sulfur as cell cathode for LSBs [138]. The excellent reversible redox reaction of elemental sulfur and low resistance at the electrode/electrolyte interfaces can be realized based on the designed 3D-array structure. The structure also provides facilitated transmission paths for Li+. Overall, a variety of array structured carbon materials, including but not limited to the carbon materials previously mentioned, have undergone extensive researches and preparation. They have also been widely used to modify, dope and conduct coordination with other structural designs for enhancing electrochemical performance. 3.2 Array structured metal@carbon materials Metals as important chemical elements can be endowed and characterized based on some vital properties including excellent electron conductivity and well heat conduction based on various chemical bonds. Thus, metallic bonding can be formed according to electrostatic interactions between metal cations and delocalized electrons. According to chemical performances of metals, metals can produce sulfidic metal composites according to the covalent bonds and the coordination compounds are similar to MOFs and COFs. All in all, the problems of the electrochemical stability of various metals is rather vital not only concerned with the well stability of cathode or anode, but also concerned with the probable production of metal composites based on the extra and unwanted reactions during cycle [139]. In summary, the synergistic effect of some metals such as Co, Ni, Fe and various carbon materials with array structure eg., carbon nanowire arrays [140], CNT backbone arrays [141], and multi-functional nanowall arrays which the CNTs laid on the carbon nanowalls with porous structures [142] will make the prepared composite materials have outstanding electrochemical performance. For example, Zuo et al. synthetized the Co nanoparticle-encapsulated carbon nanowire arrays on carbon cloth as elemental sulfur host [140]. The nanowire array-modified carbon cloths acted as the based materials with high conductivity also can provide many active sites based on excellent length-diameter ratio of the obtained carbon nanowire arrays. The strong cohesion forces between the prepared Co nanoparticle and LiPSs can be improved according to the formed Co–S bonds, which facilitated the oxidation reaction and reduction reaction of sulfur species. The excellent electrochemically catalytic activities of the Co materials can be obtained during cycle. For instance, Liu et al. synthesized the N-doped CNT backbone arrays metallic-Co as presented in Fig. 5 (a) as sulfur for LSBs [141]. The N-doped CNT backbone arrays metallic-Co still can maintain a polyhedral structure, with the dense CNT backbone arrays inserted from both the internal surface and outside surface of the polyhedron, which will be rather helpful to retain the structure stability of cell cycle. The in-situ grown N-doped CNT backbone arrays can form a complete intersecting high conductivity network, which can absorb LiPSs and suppress the dissolution and diffusion of LiPSs. Meanwhile, the hollow structure also can guarantee the “perfect” interfacial contacting between elemental sulfur and liquid electrolyte, which is rather helpful for fast redox reactions. Thus, the LSBs presented excellent electrochemical performance. Moreover, Sun et al. prepared multi-functional nanowall arrays which the CNTs adhered on the porous carbon nanowalls based on the help of the cobalt catalyst as shown in Fig. 5(b) as the cathode of LSBs [142]. The combined conductive network including vertically aligned transmission pathways were helpful for facilitated transmission of Li+ and electrons, presenting good reaction kinetics. The roles between the “physical confinement” of LiPSs in the vertically aligned channels and excellent chemical adsorption also can effectively reduce the LiPSs dissolution. Additionally, the CNTs confined on the nanowalls can “riveted” the elemental sulfur, thus ensuring excellent contacting between active materials and the CNTs, and enabling the well utilization of active materials. And the formed tri-phase interfaces among elemental sulfur, electrolyte and sulfur host also can provide outstanding electrochemical reactions during the cycle. Meanwhile, the produced Li2S can be deposited on the nanowalls. And the grooves among the nanowalls also can be role in formation of Li+ transmission pathways and are able of reducing the large volumetric change during redox processes. In addition, the entangled cobalt-nitrogen-carbon nanotube array electrode including Co nanoparticles as presented in Fig. 5(c) also was synthesized for LSBs by Sun et al. [143]. The electrode including the CNTs with excellent transmission networks of electrons and good flexibility can ensure facilitated to obtain high electronic conductivity and realize enough room to adapt to huge volume changes for electrode. The array structure and polar N species can reduce the LiPSs shuttling. Last but not least, the catalytic role of the applied Co nanoparticles as efficient accelerator for sulfur conversion, the redox reaction can be fasten, therefore reducing the gathering of the soluble LiPSs and suppressing their shuttling for LSBs during cycle. Thus the cathode including array structured materials can obtain well loading of active materials and present ultra-high battery cycling stability. Meanwhile, Morteza et al. synthesized the Co nanowire/carbon nanofiber arrays including hierarchical structures as presented in Fig. 5(d) as sulfur host [144]. The large gap between the array tubes can provide high sulfur accessibility as shown in Fig. 5(e), which facilitated the excellent electrochemical reactions with fast transport channels of Li+. Meanwhile, the combination of the CNFs and the CoNWs also can lower their contacting resistances. More importantly, the composite can reduce “shuttle effect” of LiPSs by strong confining them. Besides Co metal is prepared and applied in the array structured materials, metal Ni also is fabricated combining some array structured materials for LSBs. For instance, Xia et al. prepared the binder-free Ni@N-doped carbon nanospheres films via a facile way as shown in Fig. 5(f) as sulfur host [145]. The cross-linked Ni@N-doped carbon nanospheres films can improve the electrical conductivity of cell materials and provide physical “confinement” toward high-order LiPSs. Meanwhile, the doped N heteroatoms and superficial NiO layer on Ni layer also can together play a role to effectively suppress “shuttle effect” of LiPSs. And the combined effect of N and polar Ni can improve the reaction kinetics during the redox and provided the excellent chemical adsorption to high-order LiPSs. According to these, the LSBs presented outstanding electrochemical performance. All in all, the composite materials including metallic simple substance and carbon materials have many advantages for array structured materials, which can integrate the advantages of metallic simple substance, carbon materials and main-designed array structure, effectively improving the electrochemical performance and safety of LSBs. But, the most challenging issue with using pure metallic simple substance is high cost and difficulty in achieving uniform dispersion of array structure and metallic simple substance in various carbon materials. In addition, in the process of selecting pure metallic simple substance, their types are also limited. Based on these problems, metallic simple substance combining array structured carbon materials still need further be enhanced. 3.3 Array structured metal oxide As everyone knows, metal oxides including an anion of oxygen in the oxidation state of O2− usually have excellent polar surface, which can trap and confine LiPSs. When compared to various carbon substances, metal oxides can provide many polar active sites for confinement of LiPSs. Benefiting from own disadvantages and special band structures, many metal oxides even also have excellent electron conductivity. In addition, the final volumetric energy density can be enhanced based on preparation and application of metal oxides and sulfur composites due to high inherent density of metal oxides combining carbon materials [146]. Here, some main metal oxides are introduced as sulfur species combining carbon materials for LSBs. In the following content, some typical metal oxides including Mn3O4, ZnO, TiO2, Ti4O7, Co3O4, V2O5, and VO2 presenting huge advantages of oxides for LSBs will be introduced in detail. Usually, Mn3O4 has many advantages such as its rich resources, environmentally friendly, easy one-step direct preparation and low cost. Further, Mn3O4 also can ensure the good electronic conductivity facilitating the fast charge transfer based on the cell electrode. And Mn3O4 has much stronger chemical absorption of LiPSs and more stability than that of MnO2 in the liquid electrolyte after adsorbing with high-order LiPSs [147]. For instance, Zhang et al. prepared nano-wall-array Mn3O4 as the main materials for LSBs [148]. The nano-wall arrays can be regarded as “nano and reasonable reservoirs” for effective adsorption and restriction of active materials. Meanwhile, the nano-wall-array Mn3O4 also can present well chemical stability when binding with LiPSs, bringing the long-lasting suppression on the LiPSs shuttling. Thus the LSBs presented outstanding electrochemical performance. Zinc oxide (ZnO), as an ionic crystal, has a greater potential for LSBs because of its environmentally friendly, rich resources, strong adsorption energy for LiPSs and outstanding closing contact between active materials and liquid electrolyte [149]. Meanwhile, when metal oxide ZnO is doped with other high-valence metal, the electronic conductivity of metal oxide ZnO also can be further enhanced, which enhance its adsorption and catalysis performance for LSBs. For example, Kumar et al. prepared a bio-inspired, brush-like interlayer consisting of ZnO nanowires and interconnected conductive frameworks as shown in Fig. 6 (a) for LSBs [150]. The brush-like nano-architecture can form and construct on a thin and interconnected conductive framework, which can further enhance the confinement of LiPSs. Subsequently, a reasonable ordered structure based on the ZnO nanoprism-arrays in the N-doped carbon foam nanoplates including multi-walled CNTs [151] and the ultra-fine ZnO nanocrystals decorated 3D macroporous polypyrrole inverse opal using the SiO2 sphere arrays as the template as shown in Fig. 6(b) [152] have been prepared for LSBs, respectively. Titanium dioxide (TiO2), which is mainly from anatase (α-TiO2), rutile (β-TiO2), brookite (γ-TiO2), and bronze, usually is a naturally occurring oxide of titanium. It has been proved that TiO2 can be regarded as a promising host for LiPSs due to hydrophilic Ti–O groups, strong electrostatic attraction (S–Ti–O) with moderate polar on LiPSs, and excellent chemical absorption ability. Firstly, some composites including carbon materials, TiO2 and sulfur or sulfur compounds have been applied in the sulfur cathode materials [153]. For example, Zhu et al. prepared polypyrrole (PPy)/TiO2 nanotube arrays with coaxial heterogeneous structure acted as cathode materials of LSBs [154]. The formed architecture also was beneficial for confining LiPSs for reducing LiPSs shuttling. Finally, the overall performance of battery can be realized. Furthermore, some array structured TiO2 materials are also composited with nanofiber structured materials in electrodes to further improve cell performance. Xiong et al. and Zhang et al. prepared in situ-grown polar TiO2 nanowire array on carbon nanofibers with binder-free and “room-like” TiO2 array on titanium foil with standing TiO2 regarding as walls and a lid of dense nanofibers as a roof as sulfur hosts, respectively [155,156]. Many electrons from the current collector also can be conducted along the standing polar TiO2 nanowire array and TiO2 walls to enhance electrochemical reactions. The array and roofed structure also can change the concentration direction and then maintain and confine these LiPSs in the region of cathode. Meanwhile, the large volume expansion and contraction of electrode materials during cycle can be adapted to the change based on the adequate space provided by the array and roofed structure. In addition, some composites of LiPSs such as Li2S8 or Li2S6 and array structured TiO2 is also used in the cathode of LSBs. Chen et al. directly dropped the soluble Li2S8 on hierarchically architecture carbon coated TiO2 nanowire with array structure as shown in Fig. 6(c) as cathode [157]. The nanostructure can endow a huge internal room between nanowires to adapt to huge volume expansion and contraction of electrode materials during cycle, thus ensuring the large contacting between active substance and C-TiO2 nanowire arrays. And based on introduction of carbon atoms, the increase of electron conductivity of the intricately intertwined 3D network also can lower the intrinsic resistance and enhance the usage rate of active materials. More importantly, the nanowire arrays also can provide strong adsorption of LiPSs, facilitating the reaction kinetics of redox reaction and suppressing the LiPSs shuttling. Finally, the LSBs presented impressive specific discharge capacity and high Columbic efficiency. As well is known, many carbon or metal materials combining elemental sulfur can enhance the usage rate of active materials, improve the electronic conductivity of sulfur electrode and endow the strong adsorption and confinement of LiPSs. Thus researchers combined the merits of array structured TiO2 with some carbon materials including novel structures to enhance the electrochemical properties of LSBs. For instance, Wu et al. and Zhu et al. designed and synthesized a hierarchical MXene@TiO2 nanoarray and hollow C@TiO2 array nanospheres for the main cathode materials of LSBs, respectively [158,159]. The formed TiO2 nanosheet array can significantly suppress the “shuttle effect” of LiPSs through strong chemical adsorption between polar TiO2 and polar LiPSs. Meanwhile, the TiO2 nanosheet array with large specific surface area can produce many contacting areas with the electrolyte and present many adsorption sites of LiPSs to enhance the redox reaction and further effectively absorb LiPSs. According to the above mentioned advantages, the LSBs both showed prominent specific discharge capacity and excellent long-term cycle. In the aspect of metal-TiO2 array composite, Wang et al. prepared nickel-decorated TiO2 nanotube arrays as sulfur host [160]. The TiO2 nanotube arrays with high specific surface area can present enough space for oxidation and reduction reaction, and facilitated conduction channels for Li+ and electrons. Meanwhile, the introduction of nickel also can improve the electric conductivity of the cathode materials and present strong adsorption role for LiPSs, thus effectively suppressing “shuttle effect”. Ti4O7 is belonging to the Ti n O2 n −1 Magnéli phases, which is substoichiometric constitutes of metallic titanium oxides forming a similar succession combining TiO2 and Ti2O3. Usually, Ti4O7 can be applied as a functional catalyzer because of its excellent electrical conductivity.
