More importantly, Ti4O7 mainly includes the polar O–Ti–O units with excellent adsorption for LiPSs, which is vital important for retarding dissolution of LiPSs when regarded as electrode for LiPSs. Recently, Chen et al. prepared the Magnéli phase Ti4O7 nanotube arrays grown on titanium nitride mesh based materials as shown in Fig. 6(d) for LSBs [161]. The structure of Ti4O7 nanotube arrays can allow enough entrance of elemental sulfur for electrolyte and realize high loading of active materials. Meanwhile, the array architecture also can provide physical adsorption of LiPSs and enough transmission channels of Li+. Transition metal oxide Co3O4 is highly favored by many researchers because of its low cost price, rich sources and excellent catalytic performance. More importantly, when Co3O4 is applied in battery systems, it has aroused wide attention because of its advantages such as excellent theoretical capacity, outstanding tap density and stable chemical properties. MacFarlane et al. fabricated the Co3O4 nanoneedle arrays as presented in Fig. 6(e) as a multi-functional “super-reservoir” electrode acted as sulfur host for LSBs [162]. The features for the carbon cloth@Co3O4 nanoneedle array convincingly presented reversible sedimentation/disintegration of the active materials, ensuring the dual roles of Co3O4 nanoneedles to enhance the redox processes. Recently, many cobalt oxide materials with similar oxygen vacancy defects have also been prepared and successfully applied in LSBs. For example, Yang et al. prepared the porous core-shell Co@CoO1− x nanosheet array grown on carbon cloth as sulfur host for LSBs [163]. The porous 2D nanosheet array structure can provide the CoO1− x shells with sufficiently exposed active sites, bringing excellent LiPSs adsorption. And enough oxygen vacancies also can improve the electrical conductivities of cathode materials including CoO1− x shells and promote the breakage of the S–S bond in the adsorbed LiPSs. More importantly, the metallic Co cores including few grain boundaries coupled with carbon cloth can form the complete and successive conductive networks, which can achieve facilitated electron transfer from carbon cloth to CoO1− x surfaces to speed up the immobilized conversion of LiPSs. Based on cooperated role of CoO1− x shells and well conductive Co cores, the carbon cloth/Co@CoO1− x host enabled the LSBs with excellent performance. Among various catalysts including metals, metal carbides, metal oxides, metal sulfides, metal nitrides and metal phosphides, Nb2O5 has aroused much interests because of its some merits such as natural abundance, high corrosion resistance and excellent lithium ions conductivity at surface and in bulk based on its unique Nb–O crystal structure and the NbO6 octahedral between (001) providing 2D channels for fast transportation of lithium ions. When compared with other metal oxides, the prepared Nb2O5 has been proven to be more sulfophilic because of the strong ionic Li–O bonds between Nb2O5 and LiPSs. More importantly, the Nb2O5 nanocrystals usually can greatly enhance the redox kinetics from soluble LiPSs to insoluble LiPSs which are thought as an ideal accelerator for redox processes [164]. Wang et al. fabricated the unique niobium oxide matrix with amorphous/crystalline heterostructured Nb2O5 with 3D ordered macroporous architecture based on the disposal of the PMMA array template and the convertion of niobium salt as presented in Fig. 6(f) for LSBs [165]. The heterostructure of Nb2O5 can improve the overall electronic conduction based on the facilitated electron transport channels. Summing up the merits of amorphous Nb2O5 with strong adsorption of sulfur species and crystalline Nb2O5 with facilitated Li conduction, the electrodes can reduce and suppress the “shuttle effect” of LiPSs and boost the reaction kinetics. More importantly, the 3D ordered macroporous structure and excellent lithiophilicity of the heterostructured Nb2O5 can contribute an important role to favorable regulations on lithium plating and stripping processes, leading to the effectively suppressed growth of lithium dendrite and improved redox reversibility. Finally, the cell presented outstanding electrochemical performance. V2O5, a layer-structured transition metal oxide, is widely used in energy storage fields including secondary batteries. Meanwhile, different V2O5 architectures such as nanorod, nanosphere, nanofiber, nanoflower, nanotube, nanowire, etc. have been exploited, designed, and prepared for wide applications in Li batteries [166]. Because of strong catalytic roles and excellent adsorption with the produced LiPSs, V2O5 also have been prepared for LSBs. Zhu et al. innovatively prepared a 3D heterostructure of V2O5 nanotube arrays vertically grown on V2C-MXenes as sulfur host [167]. High specific surface area and tubular morphology of the V2O5 nanotube arrays vertically grown on V2C-MXenes can effectively increase the sulfur loading with the stable structure of electrode using the V2C nanosheet as substrate. The V2O5@V2C constructed based on this method also can lower the stack of V2C nanosheet and realize the long-term and strong adsorption of soluble LiPSs to reduce the adverse effects of the LiPSs shuttling. More importantly, under the synergistic effect of V2O5′s outstanding catalytic ability and excellent carrier mobility of V2C, the electrochemically reacted rate of the electrode can be greatly improved. Among the transition metal substances, VO2 has its distinctiveness which the potential of redox reaction is a bit higher than that of LiPSs (about 2.4 V), which makes it chemical reactive with LiPSs. Sun et al. prepared a 3D free-standing hierarchical structure of paramontroseite VO2 nanoparticles grown on N-doped carbon nanotube arrays as sulfur host with strong catalytic performance [168]. The 3D structure with vertically aligned N-doped carbon nanotube arrays have large surface area and make their uniform distribution and also can facilitate the electrons and Li+ transport between elemental sulfur and enhance electrode conductivity. Nowadays, many thin-layered metal hydroxides including Ni(OH)2 have been prepared and applied in LSBs due to effective encapsulation for elemental sulfur, thus irreversibly reacting with lithium ions, finally providing strong adsorption of LiPSs. For example, Xu et al. synthesized 2D vertical arrays of Ni(OH)2 with enough hydrophilic hydroxyl groups@graphene nanosheet composites as sulfur host for LSBs [169]. The typical 2D nickel hydroxide@graphene nanosheet array can endow a stable barrier for LiPSs and further facilitate the conduction of electrons and lithium ions. Meanwhile, many hydrophilic hydroxyl groups in the Ni(OH)2 can also make the electrode with strong limitation and admirable chemisorption performance of LiPSs. And the heterostructure and array structure also were prepared as a sulfur carrier to realize high sulfur loading and present excellent stability. Recently, some bi-metal compounds especially bimetallic oxides with efficient electrocatalytic performance have been widely reported for LSBs based on their roles as additives or sulfur host, which should be able to fast catalyze the redox kinetics of LiPSs to re-utilize the confined them in the region of cathode, along with its chemisorption toward LiPSs and fast conductivity of lithium ions. For example, Liu et al. prepared the electrocatalytic NiCo2O4 nanofiber arrays on carbon cloth for flexible LSBs [72]. The 3D network formed by the interconnected carbon cloth fibers can significantly increase the reaction sites for accelerating the reaction process and greatly reduce the large volume expansion and contraction of sulfur cathode especially in the case of high sulfur loading [170]. Meanwhile, the prepared NiCo2O4 also had an excellent adsorption toward soluble LiPSs and thus can greatly reduce their shuttling. Meanwhile, the combination of metal Co and Zn, their formed bi-metal compounds also have been applied in LSBs. Zhao et al. prepared the rGO-coated zinc-cobalt oxide nanosheet arrays with the N-doped carbon anchored on the carbon cloths as main materials of LSBs [171]. The porous 3D interconnected ZnCo precursor nanosheet arrays and the formed porous organic ligand nanosheets can endow a stable electrochemical reaction framework, which can adapt to huge volume expansion and contraction of electrode materials, enhancing electrochemical stability. Metal titanium oxide (MTO), which has been extensively applied as electrode substance for recyclable batteries, also can be regarded as a LiPSs adsorbent because of an interaction between the polar parts including titanium and oxygen and the LiPSs. For instance, Liu et al. and Guo et al. synthesized the Na2Ti6O13 (NTO) nanowire array grown on the carbon cloth and the 3D Li4Ti5O12 nanowire array as a highly effective multi-functional sulfur host for LSBs, respectively [172,173]. For former, in the arrayed structure, the synergetic co-adsorption sites from the exposed Ti and Na cations can strongly ensure the NTO-facilitated to quicken the transform of high-order to low-order LiPSs and ensure excellent adsorption to high-order LiPSs. For latter, the 3D nanowire with array structure can be helpful for fast conduction of electrons and endow admirable electrochemically active surfaces, where electrons and Li+ can function with the sulfur species for facilitated conversion reaction. 3.4 Array structured metal sulfide@carbon materials At present, among various candidates of electrode materials, transition-metal sulfides (TMSs) stood out and have gained increasing much attention. As a cathode of LSBs, TMSs have been employed to overcome the issues of cycled LSBs. When compared with some carbon-based hosts which can reduce the LiPSs shuttling based on the physical limitation, transitional metal sulfides usually present the strong interaction with the LiPSs due to polar interaction or Lewis acid base interaction besides physical limitation. As a half-metal with well electron conductivity, cobalt disulfide or other sulfur cobalt composite materials have been presented as a sulfiphilic host for accelerating the LiPSs redox reaction. And the conductive cobalt sulfide cathode also can present excellent selectrochemical performance than those of ordinary sulfur cathode. Especially, these sulfides also can accelerate surface-induced redox reaction to lower the barrier of activation energy for greatly enhancing electrochemical performance of LSBs. Wu et al. elaborately reported a novel hierarchical multi-functional cathode architecture formed through arranging the MOF-derived CoS2/carbon nanoleaf arrays into the 3D N-rich doped carbon scafold with high electron conductivity based on the self-assembly and vulcanized method for LSBs [174]. The 3D conductive network structures and MOF-derived CoS2/carbon nanoarrays can together absorb LiPSs according to the physisorption and chemisorption roles. And the flexible 3D conductive network structures also can adapt to huge volume change of electrode in the cycle processes. Meanwhile, the advanced electrocatalytic role and enhanced LiPSs redox kinetics mainly from the CoS2-CNA can be realized. All in all, the outstanding adsorption and catalysis capacity can improve the utilization of sulfur and enhance the electro-chemical performances. Meanwhile, the combining effect of CoS2 and other metal sulfides to effectively suppress the LiPSs shuttling and enhance catalytic performance has also aroused widespread interest. For instance, Guo et al. fabricated the heterostuctured Co3S4/MnS nanotube array structure as main materials of cathode for LSBs [175]. And the Mn dopants can reasonably change the electronic structure of Co3S4 to effectively confine high-order LiPSs and produce the catalytic heterogeneous surfaces to speed up the electron transport and enhance the fast reaction kinetics of sulfur species. And the 3D array structure also can significantly reduce “dead” sites caused based on the application of binder and conductive materials, and the structure also can endow fast electron transport pathways. According to these merits, the LSBs presented excellent cycle property. The CoS3, as powerful catalyzator for the solid-solid electrochemical conversion of Li2S2 to Li2S, greatly enhance sulfur utilization for electrode even high sulfur loading. Meanwhile, the CoS3 usually presents excellent role with LiPSs, thus making the confining LiPSs on its surface and ensure the reversible conversion among high-order and lower-order LiPSs. In addition, Li2S2 usually presents ultra-low dissociation energy on the surface of CoS3, strengthening the transform of Li2S2 to Li2S. For example, Sun et al. fabricated amorphous cobalt sulfide as the functional catalyst to improve the reaction kinetics and made elemental sulfur evenly dispersed in the scaffolds of the carbon paper@N-doped carbon nanotubes array@CoS3 as presented in Fig. 7 (a) for LSBs [176]. The evenly dispersed elemental sulfur had access to fast transport network structure as fabricated electrode according to the NCNTs arrays. Meanwhile, the CoS3 can be acted as an effective LiPSs immobilizer through the chemical confinement as well as the strong functional catalyst for fast transform of Li2S2 to Li2S, thus enhancing the utilization rate of elemental sulfur. Thus the LSBs using the electrode showed excellent electrochemical performances. The Co9S8 nanocrystals present highly polar and quasi-metallic, it can strongly absorb and confine with LiPSs and reduce their outward diffusion staying away from the cathode electrode material of LSBs. For example, Xu et al. and Manthiram et al. prepared hollow metallic and polar Co9S8 with well-aligned tubular arrays as shown in Fig. 7(b) and MOF derived Co9S8 array anchored onto 3D graphene foam grown via chemical vapor deposition as cathode materials of LSBs, respectively [177,178]. The hollow structure in the two materials can lower even suppress the “LiPSs shuttling” and present enough room to store elemental sulfur and adapt to large volume expansion. And the well-aligned arrays also can provide the transmission channels for fast conduction of electrons and Li+. Furthermore, the Co9S8 can absorb the polar LiPSs for enhancing the cycle life because of excellent chemisorptive ability for further adsorbing and confining the LiPSs. Meanwhile, the Co9S8 also presented an outstanding catalytic function in enhancing the redox reaction. Thus the LSBs both showed admirable electrochemical performances. In addition, a novel free-standing Co9S8 polyhedron array derived from ZIF-67 growing on a 3D carbon cloth also was fabricated as sulfur host by Liu et al. [179]. The cathode had some characteristics based on the Co9S8 polyhedron array. The structure did not require any functional additives for cell electrode, further lowering the additional weight and side effects. The polyhedron array can adapt to the large volume and significantly reduce the aggregation and loss of active materials during cycle. And the polar Co9S8 also can provide excellent chemical confinement to reduce LiPSs shuttling, which can reduce LiPSs shuttling. The recoverable electrochemical performance and excellent cycle stability can be realized for LSBs. As everyone knows, Co-based metal-Se compounds such as CoSe are helpful, maybe because of excellent electronic conductivity and catalytic performance derived from Co materials. Meanwhile, the Co-based metal-Se compounds usually present multi-functional roles of improving conductivity, confining LiPSs, facilitating the diffusion of Li+, catalyzing the redox reaction of LiPSs and dissociation of Li2S2/Li2S. So some Co-Se compounds have been applied for LSBs. For example, Zhang et al. prepared the conductive CoSe2 nanoarrays as efficient electrocatalyst for LSBs [180]. Firstly, the metallic CoSe2 owned excellent electronic conductivity to facilitate electrons transfer. Secondly, the CoSe2 nanoarrays presented the excellent polar interface to confine soluble LiPSs. Thirdly, the excellent electrocatalytic ability of CoSe2 was helpful to quicken the redox reaction of LiPSs and suppress LiPSs shuttling. Furthermore, the nanowire array structure of C@CoSe2 also can afford enough chemisorption and catalyst sites to strengthen the performance of LSBs. Finally, the atomic level analysis also revealed that the CoSe2 could weaken the Li–S bond of Li2S molecule by S–Co and Li–Se bonds, which decreased the decomposition barriers and facilitated the decomposition of Li2S. According to these advantages, the LSB presented well electrochemical performance and good safety. In addition, CoSe2 is modified to have more defects to further improve the catalytic performance of the material and enhance the reaction kinetics of the cell. Guan et al. prepared the MOF-derived bi-functional Co0.85Se nanoparticles implanted in the N-doped carbon nanosheet arrays as cathode for LSBs. The interconnected porous carbonbased structure of the Co0.85Se/N-doped carbon nanosheet arrays can provide the fast transmission channels for electrons and ions, enhancing the reaction kinetics. The Co0.85Se nanoparticles through the based materials of N-doped carbon nanosheet arrays with large specific surface and excellent strength also can absorb and catalyze LiPSs, thus promoting the redox reaction and protecting for cathode [181]. According to these merits, the LSBs presented high utilization rate of sulfur species including outstanding rate and long cycle performance. Recently, Qiu et al. fabricated the B, N-codoped carbon nanotube array decorated with sulfilic and lithiophilic CoSe nanoparticles grown on a carbon cloth as as electrode for LSBs [182]. The unique B, N-codoped carbon nanotube array structure implanted with the CoSe nanoparticles was beneficial for the adsorption and conversion of LiPSs combining the physical limit and chemical adsorption, and they also were favorable for the homogeneous deposition of metal Li. The CoSe@B, N-codoped carbon nanotube array/carbon cloth both can simultaneously presented excellent catalytic effects for fastening LiPSs conversion. Meanwhile, the CoSe@N-codoped carbon nanotube array/carbon cloth-Li anode with stable CE also can obtain lithium dendrite-free during cycle. Benefiting from these synergistic effects, the LSBs presented excellent electrochemical performance. At present, transition metal sulfides or selenides (TMSs/TMSes) are looked forward to be hopeful candidates of cathode materials due to excellent density and outstanding electronic conductivity even good electrocatalytic performance. In addition, some related reports also have presented that reasonably morphology engineering of TMSs/TMSes is an attractive way to control the physical and chemical performances through changing the specific surface area, catalytic sites and porous structure of TMSs/TMSes. For example, Hu et al. fabricated the P-doped NiSe2 nanorods arrays grown on activated carbon cloth based materials for LSBs [183]. The P-doping can improve the electron conduction between the P-NiSe2 and high-order LiPSs, bringing the enhanced chemical adsorptions and strong catalytic roles for the redox reaction. These merits also can effectively reduce the LiPSs shuttling and improve the utilization rate of active materials. The well interactions and outstanding catalysis of the P-NiSe2 on LiPSs also can make 3D growth of Li2S2/Li2S on the P-NiSe2/activated carbon cloth cathode, obtaining effective adapt to huge volume changes. According to these advantages, the LSBs can present high specific discharge capacity and outstanding high-rate performance. And recently, some researchers also prepared transition metal sulfides-nickel disulfide and applied them in LSBs. For instance, Shi et al. prepared the in-situ growth of NiS2 nanosheet array on the Ni foil as cathode materials of LSBs [184]. The unique nanostructure of the NiS2 nanosheet array can present enough active sites for the well confinement and chemical action of LiPSs. Meanwhile, the NiS2 nanosheet array also can provide facilitated transmission channels for electrons and Li+. According to these advantages, the cell using the electrode showed admirable cycle performance. Vanadium disulfide (VS2) is a extremely representative composition of the metal dichalcogenide family with the ignorable band gap. The metallic performance has already made VS2, especially its 2D form, to present a versatile platform for multi-functional use such as supercapacitor, nano-electronics and electrocatalytic performance. In the regime of LiPSs, VS2 has presented hopeful promise for regarding as main materials of cathode. For instance, Sun et al. fabricated a free-standing structure of walnut-morphological VS4 nanosites combining with the CNTs arrays as presented in Fig. 7(c) as cathodes of LSBs [185]. In the framework, the formed arrays can provide excellent specific surface area and excellent conductivity for the electrodes with high sulfur loading. More importantly, the prepared VS4 nanosites with the CNTs arrays can facilitate to trap, absorb and form the strong catalytic conversions of LiPSs. Recently, many transition-metal disulfides with efficient catalytic performance such as MoS2, TiS2, NbS2 and so on which can obtain relatively strong chemical interactions with LiPSs, which have attracted much wide interest. Especially, MoS2 has been confirmed to afford enough polar active sites for reducing LiPSs shuttle to obtain long cycle stability. For example, Zhang et al. integrated the respective merits of metal sulfide and oxide with the array structure to prepare the hierarchical SnO2/1T-MoS2 nanoarray as shown in Fig. 7(d) as the composition for LSBs [186]. The large gaps or pores between SnO2 nanosheets can largely accommodate huge volume expansion or contraction of cathode during cycle and bring about the accessed penetration of liquid electrolyte, thus providing the facilitated transportation of Li+. And the excellent electron conductivity of 1 T-MoS2 nanoarray also can provide enough edge sites and facilitated electrons transport, thus greatly quickening the redox reactions of LiPSs. The electrochemical performance and safety of LSBs can be significantly enhanced. In addition, Co–S bond and Fe–S bond can be form for owning excellent binding energy and electron transfer for LiPSs in the reported according to an analogous periodic law. Inspired by the comparable catalytic performance, some researchers have fabricated some Co–Fe bimetallic sulfides on CP substrate as the functional interlayer in LSBs. Besides using CP as physical confinement, the chemical adsorbing sites and catalytic role of Co–Fe bimetallic sulfide are one of the effective advance methods to suppress LiPSs shuttling. The Co and Fe ions in bi-metal sulfides can be regarded to together strengthen chemical adsorption and accelerate redox conversion for sulfur species, which can realize more stable long-term cycle than these of mono-metallic sulfides. Besides the application of single metal sulfide in cell electrode materials of LSBs, bi-metallic sulfide materials have enhanced the electrochemical performance because of their more defects and active sites, stronger polarity characteristics and faster electron and Li+ transport channels when compared with single metal sulfide. Guo et al. and Liu et al. prepared a flexible sulfur host composed of FeCo2S4 nanotube arrays grown on the surface of carbon cloth as shown in Fig. 7(e) and the freestanding Fe0.4Co8.6S8 nanotube/nanosheet arrays on carbon cloth to host SeS2 for LSBs and Li/SeS2 batteries [187,188]. Besides the improved physical confinement with the array structure, the Fe0.4Co8.6S8 also also can present strong ability of chemical immobilization for LiPSs/LiPSes. The enviable electrochemical performance can be obtained for LSBs using these electrodes. Besides the preparation of bi-metallic sulfides by combining metal Fe with cobalt sulfide, the materials composed of Zn and Ni with cobalt sulfide are also used in electrode materials of LSBs. Su et al. prepared porous NiCo2S4 nanoneedle arrays adhered on carbon cloths as support body of cathode for LSBs [189]. The porous NiCo2S4 nanoneedle arrays with high electronic conductivity and abundant porous structure can present facilitated conduction pathways of electrons and Li+. The porous structure also can accommodate to huge volume expansion and contraction of cell electrode. More importantly, the strong absorbability and the excellent catalytic effect of NiCo2S4 can expedite the adsorption and transform of LiPSs. Benefiting from the above advantages, the LSBs presented outstanding electrochemical performance. Recently, Chen et al. prepared bi-metal sulfide (CoZn-S) nanosheet arrays with sulfur vacancies and dense heterointerfaces as presented in Fig. 7(f) for accelerating the transform of active materials and enhancing cell performances [190]. The S-vacancy and build-in interfacial field in the CoZn-S can accelerate the electron conduction and reasonably change the electronic structure of the materials. Through combining the anion vacancies and heterogeneous interfaces into transition metal chalcogenides, the local coordination and electronic structure can be regulated to enhance the electrocatalytic activity for realizing fast transform between elemental sulfur and LiPSs. And the nanosheet arrays can provide facilitated Li+-transport pathways, accommodate huge volume change and maintain structural stability during cycle. The electrochemical performance can be significantly improved. 3.5 Array structured metal nitride@carbon materials For better seeking out an effective and cheap catalyst as a substitutable to noble metals, some metal nitrides have brought about wide interest due to their long records in different catalytic applications. Especially, various metal nitrides have prepared as highly efficient electrocatalysts for various electrocatalysis including oxidation-reduction of nitrogen. The excellent catalytic activity of metal nitrides mainly is attributed to the unique electronic structure, which can make sure the suitable confinement between the surface of nitrides and active materials during cycle Meanwhile, most of metal nitrides also usually have excellent electronic conductivity according to the range metallic materials, which is rather helpful for fast electron transfer of cell electrodes during cycle. Co4N materials usually present excellent electrical conductivity and strong affinity for LiPSs. And Co4N materials also can catalyze the facilitated transform between high-order LiPSs and low-order LiPSs (Li2S2/Li2S). Thus, the Co4N also is widely used in LSBs. For example, Qiu et al. applied the cobalt nitride (Co4N) nanoparticles to embed the porous carbon nanosheet arrays grown on flexible carbon cloth as presented in Fig. 8 (a and b) and the p-n Co9S8-Co4N heterostructure implanted within hollow carbon nanosheet arrays grown on carbon cloth as presented in Fig. 8(c and d) as sulfur hosts, respectively [191,192]. For former, the nanohybrids including the 3D interconnected networks can facilitate transportation of Li+ and electrons. More importantly, the Co4N not only strongly adsorbed the LiPSs, but also accelerated reaction kinetics between elemental sulfur and LiPSs. For latter, enough active sites and boundary defects produced by the Co9S8-Co4N heterostructures can enhance the nucleation and redox reaction of Li2S. Meanwhile, the hollow and nanosheet array structure can present high sulfur loading and supply enough room for reducing huge volume change. Combining these merits, the LSBs both presented excellent specific discharge capacity, outstanding rate capacity and ultra-stable long cycle. Furthermore, the appropriate modifications are conducted to Co4N materials for obtaining some defective Co4N materials, making the electrocatalysis and adsorption of LiPSs more effective. Finally, these merits will further enhance cell performance. For instance, Gu et al. synthesized a 3D interconnected architecture including the mutually embedded CNT arrays with Co nanoparticles and dispersed Co-N x species on a carbon foam as cathode materials for LSBs [193]. Firstly, the materials possessed 3D interconnected conductive network, as well as Co nanoparticles and Co-N x active sites decorated on the CNTs (Co-NCNT@CF). Secondly, the interconnected conductive carbon networks can provide a fast transmission pathway for facilitating electrons and Li+. Thirdly, the electrode with high surface area and large pore volume can enhance sulfur loading and provide an enough exposure of the Co-N x active sites to confine LiPSs. Finally, the well-designed Co-N x active sites can reasonably adjust the catalytic conversion of LiPSs and enhance the reaction kinetic by the modification of electronic distribution Co-NCNT@CF as cathode materials. As well known, TiN with excellent electronic conductivity has been applied as an excellent-efficiency immobilizer and catalyzer of LiPSs. Ng et al. synthesized the TiN nanotubes arrays through the anodization of Ti foils and nitridation for cathode of LSBs [194]. The TiN nanotubes arrays equipped with longer length and thinner diameter can provide excellent performance including electrical conductivity and chemical stability. Meanwhile, the matrix, including titanium nitride nanotubes showed an improved the utilization rate of active materials through suppressing the diffusion of soluble LiPSs and decrease the charge transfer impedance. Thus the electrochemical performance of LSBs can be significantly enhanced. Furthermore, TiN materials with special structures are also used in LSBs with Li2S6 as electrodes, which enhances the performance of the LSBs. Chen et al. prepared a bi-functional cathode substrate configured with 3D TiN nanowire arrays with exposed (200) facets for Li2S6-based LSBs [195]. Benefiting from the effective chemical tailoring way, the 3D TiN nanowire arrays-based electrode can provide stable well-dispersed and highly ordered nanowires to promote the efficient transition of redox charge carriers and to further improve the redox reaction of LiPSs conversion. Meanwhile, the five-coordinated Ti sites on (200) facets also can improve the adsorptivity for LiPSs, which can accelerate the utilization of sulfur and reduce the LiPSs movement. The TiN nanowire can be grown on carbon cloth without additional binders or low capacity conductors. And the 3D architecture electrode also can form enough multiscale interspace for liquid Li2S6 solution and electrolyte. Meanwhile, some modified TiN materials also are applied for LSBs based on the enhanced electronic conductivity and catalytic performance. Recently, Guo et al. prepared the S-doped titanium nitride (S-TiN) catalytic array for LSBs [196]. The array structure as an easily permeable architecture with facilitated electron conduction allowed the outstanding wettability toward liquid electrolyte, thus making sure the high utilization rate of active materials. The S-TiN also also can fasten the transform of soluable LiPSs to insoluble LiPSs and greatly suppress the shuttle effect, ensuring long-term stability of LSBs. Because of the well performance in the aspect of electronic conductivity for VN, the VN substance usually presents lower polarization phenomenon and accelerated redox reaction than most of carbon materials. Meanwhile, high utilization of active materials also can be realized based on the excellent interfacial conductivity, stable chemical confinement for LiPSs and strong catalytic performance for LiPSs transformation. For example, Zhan et al. prepared self-supported VN arrays coupled with the N-doped carbon nanotubes embedded with the Co nanoparticles with strong catalytic performance for LSBs [197]. The enviably conductive VN, Co and N-doped carbon nanotubes can be grown on the applied carbon cloth, which could accelerate the electron conduction. The high surface area of the MOF-derived Co@N-doped carbon nanotubes was rather beneficial for smooth deposition of Li2S on it. The polar Co and VN together had excellent physical confinement and chemical adsorption to LiPSs to prevent their shuttling. Both VN and Co can be acted as excellent electrocatalysts to speed up the transform between sulfur species, enhancing the redox reaction and improving the utilization rate of active materials. The electrochemical performance can be significantly enhanced. 3.6 Array structured metal phosphide@carbon materials With the rapid expansion of metal oxide, sulfides and nitrides for excellent catalytic effect, some metal phosphides including CoP, iron phosphide (FeP), Ni2P, MoP and so on have been regarded as excellent representatives of the rapid development area of non-precious metal electrocatalysts. For example, FeP usually own some merits such as low-cost in production while being well catalytic towards the sulfur redox conversions. Meanwhile, some researchers also have presented that FeP own strong chemical adsorption to LiPSs with reasonable adsorption energies in the suitable range which is helpful for their fast redox conversions according to DFT [198,199]. For example, Yu et al. prepared the structure of CF/FeP@C nanotube arrays as shown in Fig. 9 (a and b) as cathode for LSBs [200]. The carbon nanotube array can optimize the electrical properties of electrode materials. The FeP might as well greatly reduce the “shuttle effect” of LiPSs and advance its transformation. And the movement of the center of the P band in FeP can quicken the electron transport of interface layer through improving electronic concentration in the Fermi energy for adsorption of Li2S4, improving the kinetics of chemical reaction. Thus the LSBs presented showed ultrastable cycle life with high capacity retention after long cycle. CoP, as a membrane of metal phosphide, also has been used as a cathode material for LSBs. The phenomenon mainly is attributed to some merits such as superior electronic conductivity when compared with transition metal oxide and sulfide, prior preparation ways to nitrides and carbides, a good ability to suppress the shuttling of LiPSs, outstanding catalytic capability on the conversion between soluble LiPSs and insoluble LiPSs. In view of these advantages, Yu et al. synthetized MOF-derived N-doped carbon nanoarrays with inserted CoP integrating sulfur and flexible carbon cloth through the synergistic confinement for LSBs [201]. The carbon fiber cloth and 2D carbon nanosheet arrays can construct a 3D network, which can enhance the transfer of electrons and Li+. The unique array structure not only has enough space to alleviate massive volume expansion, but also promotes physical encapsulation and chemical encapsulation of sulfides. More importantly, the CoP nanoparticles can be acted as electrocatalysts to effectively facilitate the reaction kinetics of LiPSs to improve the utilization of active materials. On account of above merits, the LSBs showed excellent specific discharge capacity with various C-rates and outstanding long-term cycling performance. Meanwhile, Shen et al. and Zhang et al. also prepared 2D N-doped carbon sheets arrays with CoP nanoparticles anchored on the carbon cloth as shown in Fig. 9(c) and MOF-derived hierarchical CoP nanoflakes anchored on vertically-erected graphene array scaffolds as presented in Fig. 9(d) to be acted as sulfur host, respectively [202,203]. For the former, the N-doped carbon sheet material prepared on carbon fiber cloth can provide an open porous structure to provide a stable space for depositing sulfur substances and form fast tracks for the facilitated spreads of Li+. The LSBs can present outstanding electrochemical performances. Based on the above research on CoP, some studies have also used metal Co with strong catalytic conversion ability and the coordinated action of preparing other metal phosphides in electrode materials of LSBs, hoping to improve batteries performance. Shao et al. prepared the integrated electrode using the layered NCNT@Co-CoP nanowire array as the main materials of cathodes for LSBs as shown in Fig. 9(e) [204]. The layered nanowire integrated electrode can provide fast and convenient transportation channels of Li+ and electrons migration. Meanwhile, the electrode materials can relieve the impact of expansion of sulfur substances. More importantly, the Co-CoP promotes the chemical capture and catalysis of LiPS in the period of cycle. Combining these advantages, the LSBs presented excellent cycling and rate performance. Recently, some metal phosphides have collaborated with CoP to make the electrochemical performance of the electrode have been further improved. For an instance, Zhang et al. synthesized Ni2P-CoP catalyst with array structure as shown in Fig. 9(f) for LSBs [205]. The hierarchical heterogeneous Ni2P-CoP catalysts can form multiple chemical bonds with S, Se, Li, etc. suppressing the shuttle effect. In addition, the hollow and hierarchical structured Ni2P-CoP catalysts exposed many catalytic active sites for LiPS and LiPSe. 3.7 Array structured electronically conducting polymer@carbon materials Conductive polymers not only have excellent electrical properties like metals, but also possess the good flexibility contained in organic polymers, and are also easy to process and prepare. In addition, several electronically conducting polymers contain functional atoms that can adsorb LiPSs such as N, S, O, etc., which has greatly developed their research on LSBs. Meanwhile, some researchers also combined electronically conducting polymers with various carbon materials or polar materials to obtain different composite materials, and the synergy between these composite materials brings the performance of LSBs more superior. Nowadays, the electronically conducting polymers mainly applied them in LSBs includes polypyrrole (PPy), polyaniline (PANI) and polythiophene (PTh) with their derivatives, e.g., poly(3,4-ethylenedioxy thiophene) (PEDOT), poly(3,4-ethylenedioxythiophene) -poly(styrenesulfonate) (PEDOT:PSS), and so on. Thus combined with these merits of electronically conducting polymers@carbon materials with array structure, these composite materials have been popularly researched in the cathode of LSBs [206,207]. PPy, as an important membrane of electronically conducting polymers exists one big p bonds. Some research workers usually synthetize PPy in the cathode of LSBs, which can improve the electron conductivity, reduce the impact of volume changes and suppress the “shuttle effect” of LiPSs as presented in Fig. 10 (a) [208–210]. the case in point is Cairns et al. and Li et al. synthetized the coaxial heterogeneous structured PPy/TiO2 nanotube arrays as presented in Fig. 10(b) and the PPy nanotubes coated with nanoscale arrays of MOFs as sulfur hosts, respectively [154,211]. For the former, embedding sulfur into highly ordered nanotube array structures is an effective method and also could offer facilitated transportation pathways for electrons. The synergistic effects of TiO2 nanotube arrays and PPy also could further bring about excellent electronically conductive framework. Moreover, the rich tubular space and PPy layers with the flexible and elastic features also can alleviate huge volumetric expansion. And the TiO2 nanotube arrays as the placode including rich exposed surfaces also can host large S species and physically absorb LiPSs up to a point, but the PPy layers along the tube wall also can improve the conductivity and stabilize of the coaxial heterogeneous structure during the cycle. Furthermore, the PPy layers also can combine with sulfur to form new stable chemical bonds to curb the diffusion of LiPSs. For the latter, the PPy nanotubes had excellent electrical conductivity which can provide the facilitated the electron transfer. At the nanoscale, UIO-66 grows on sesame like PPyNTs coated with MOFs arrays. Based on array structure, the UIO-66 owned large specific surface area and high porosity could be realized, realizing fast transmission of Li+. As is known to all, PEDOT has been obtained more attention when compared with PTh because of excellent electron conductivity, short synthesis route, simple molecular structure and high mechanical strength and stability, which is very advantageous for the transmission of electrons and Li+. Thus PEDOT or some PEDOT composites with other functional materials have been applied in LSBs. For instance, Wei et al. a structure of PEDOT nanowire array encapsulated sulfur nanoparticles as sulfur host, and the array structure uses N-doped carbon foam/CNT as the scaffold [212]. Firstly, carbon nanotubes intertwined with a 3D conductive network not only improve the conductivity of electrode, but also provide a certain degree of mechanical strength and flexibility as a skeleton. Secondly, for maintaining high sulfur loading, the parallel nanowire arrays can divide the 3D framework into many small spaces, which improves the ease of CNT coating on the surface of foam. Meanwhile, the PEDOT polymers have high conductivity and can promote electron transport in electrodes. Finally, melamine foam and array structure PANI nanowires will obtain N doping under the effect of pyrolysis, which enables the cathode surface to produce many anchor points, and has a strong adsorption effect on LiPSs. Besides, relatively high electronic conductivity and excellent adsorption performance for LiPSs, PEG also can generally transfer Li+ quickly on its own. Therefore, PEG materials are also widely used in the cathode of LSB. Zhang et al. prepared PEG carbon nanotubes with directional sulfur coating by applying PEG materials to LSBs as presented in Fig. 10(c) [213]. During the cycling process, the sulfur based coincidence point solution constructed by CNTs combined with PEG can achieve efficient lithium ion storage capacity, which is attributed to the barrier of CNT and PEG polymers in the array structure. The arrangement of CNT frameworks not only provides excellent conductivity but also constructs ordered pore channels for transmission of Li+. In addition, the barrier function of PEG polymers can effectively inhibit the shuttle effect. In summary, Table S1 shows various array structural materials, which significantly improve the electrochemical performance of the battery when applied to LSBs electrodes. Based on the above researches, the structural design and preparation of these materials have played a promoting role in development of LSBs, and can provide valuable guidance for researchers in this field. 4 Array structured materials for separators/interlayers of LSBs In addition to being used in battery electrodes, some array structured materials can also be widely used in separators or interlayers of LSBs due to special performances [214–217]. The application of modified separators or interlayers including array structured materials can also significantly suppress the LiPSs shuttling and increase the rate of redox reactions during battery cycling [218]. Meanwhile, based on these merits of modified cell separators/interlayers, the rate of Li+ transport is enhanced or modified to a certain extent, and good compatibility between separators and electrodes also can be obtained for LSBs [219]. 4.1 Array structured materials for separators 4.1.1 Carbon materials or modified carbon materials At present, besides many carbon materials are prepared and used in the cathode electrodes of LSBs, many kinds of carbon materials or modified carbon materials with array structures also are synthetized and used in separators or interlayers of high performance LSBs [220]. Various types of carbon materials as functional additives have attracted much attentions for LSBs based on their merits based on their merits such as outstanding electronic conductivity, large specific surface area, well physical and chemical stability, easy modification processes and relatively low cost, et al.. Meanwhile, the array structured carbon materials have been applied in LSBs, which are mainly attributed to the below reasons: Firstly, functional materials including array structure generally has high specific surface area, which is helpful to provide enough loading room for LiPSs and provide the enough exposure of electrodes or separators surface in liquid electrolyte, which will enhance the transport of Li+ and electrons. Secondly, the spaces between the sub-units in the array structured material also can retard large volume expansion during cycle, thus effectively protecting the electrode structure from serious collapse and provide the accumulation of stress and strain preventing the functional separators or interlayers from cracking like the traditional compact film. Thirdly, the sub-units in the array structured functional materials can be further prepared as a composite array electrode with multi-function or multistage structure as a matrix, and the merits of each content on the sub-units also can be applied cooperatively, which can further enhance the performance of the separator for LSBs. Fourthly, immobilization of active materials in array structural materials can not only ensure the active substances as uniform as possible, but also significantly lower the “wastage” of sulfur species and ultimately enhance the utilization of active materials. Fifthly, the functional materials of array structure can not only be prepared with appropriate pore size to reduce the LiPSs shuttling based on the physical confinement, but also be beneficial to materials modification for well confining LiPSs and catalyzing the transform between LiPSs or elemental sulfur and Li2S2/Li2S, which will greatly effectively suppress LiPSs shuttling, enhancing the cell performance. Furthermore, the comprehensive application of some materials with array structure and the additional multi-functional materials in LSBs also will ensure more admirable results. Meanwhile, the merits also endow these materials with array structure with novel chemical and physical performances, which can bring more opportunities to elaborately design and conduct some materials with array structure involving to more uniformly distributed active sites with excellent lithium affinity based on the material modifications and structure designs. Recently some people also have found out the practicable standpoints of combining array structured materials with other additional structure designs including different dimensional structures combining the other multi-functional materials to realize various array structured composites. And summing up the cooperative effects of advantages can be obtained for effectively making up for the shortcomings of themselves, leading to more outstanding cell performances [221–227]. As a superior type of carbon material, CNTs have been intensively researched and used in various battery systems due to their excellent mechanical durability, outstanding electrical conductivity, superbly stable chemical properties as well as easy modification. When CNTs combining array structure are applied in separator of LSBs, cell can obtain admirable electrochemical performance [228,229]. For example, Liu et al. fabricated smart blocking layer to coat on the surface of the carbon/sulfur cathode (namely an SEI-wrapped CNT/sulfur array cathode) for LSBs [230]. The formed solid electrolyte interface layers can selectively filter out lithium ions while reducing the accumulation of LiPSs and suppressing the undesired “shuttle effect” of LiPSs. The presence of liquid electrolyte interface layers including the SEI with excellent Li+ channels wrapped carbon spheres can ensure the continuous redox reaction. Combining these merits including good electrical conductivity, the high application rate of sulfur and excellent redox reaction for the LSBs can be obtained [231]. Meanwhile, many modified carbon materials have been used in the separators of LSBs. Zhan et al. prepared P doped carbon nanosheet array to modify separator through coating layer by the MgO template as presented in Fig. 11 (a) for LSBs [85]. The formed Li–P and S–P bonds can confine high-order LiPSs for avoiding the unwanted oxidation of LiPSs and present the reasonable adsorption to LiPSs [232]. More importantly, the doped P introducing surface defects and enhancing the polarity of carbon nanosheet array can enhance the effective transform among elemental sulfur, high-order LiPSs and low-order LiPSs [233]. The electrochemical performance of the assembled LSBs can be significantly improved. 4.1.2 Metal oxides As is known to all, like metal oxides applied in the electrode materials of LSBs, some metal oxides with strong polar surface, enough polar active sites for effective absorption of LiPSs, relatively excellent electronic conductivity and so on such as TiO2, Co3O4 and so on have been applied in LSBs, which the following content will be introduced in detail for metal oxides for interlayers and separators of LSBs [234–237]. For instance, Ma et al. prepared the Na-containing TiO2 nanowires/nanosheets hybrid thin layer to modify separator as presented in Fig. 11(b) for LSBs [238]. The polar performance of surface layer for Na containing TiO2 nanowires/nanosheets hybrid can enhance the wettability to liquid electrolyte, thus improving the ionic conductivity of Li+. And based on the combined action of the sandwiched sheet and nanowire mixed structure, it presented the excellent chemical confinement and the reproductive capability of sandwiched-like Na-containing TiO2 nanowires/nanosheets hybrid to confine LPSs for reducing LPSs “shuttling” [239]. Transition cobaltous oxide is highly favored by many researchers because of low cost price, enough resources and excellent catalytic performance. Furthermore, when cobaltous oxide is applied in LSBs, it has attracted wide concern due to their merits such as high theoretical discharge capacity, large tap density and stable chemical properties. According to these merits, Guo et al. synthesized the single atom array coordinated with oxygen atoms produced on the surface of ultra-thin MOF nanosheets to modify separator of LSBs [240]. The single atom array can effectively make Li ion flux be even based on the strong Li ion adsorption with O atoms at the interfaces between separator and anode, bringing good Li striping and plating. Meanwhile, at the region of cathode, the Co single atom array can be acted as “traps” to reduce LPSs shuttling by the Lewis acid-base interaction and accelerate the redox reaction kinetics for LSBs [241]. 4.1.3 Metal sulfides Nowadays, among different candidates of modified materials, transition-metal sulfdes (TMSs) presented increasing much interest. As cathode of LSBs, transitional metal sulfides have been applied to relieve problems of cycled LSBs. Compared with some pure carbon-based materials, TMSs can more suppress LPSs shuttling based on physical adsorption, the strong interaction with the LiPSs due to polar interaction or Lewis acid base interaction and certain catalytic effects [242–247]. For example, Manthiram et al. and Liu et al. conducted the metal organic framework (MOF)-derived and vertical Co9S8 hollow nanowall arrays with vertical hollow nano architecture and excellent electrical conductivity coating on a Celgard separator as presented in Fig. 12 (a) and MOF-derived Co9S8 nano-flower cluster array to modify the separator of LSBs [248,249], respectively. The Co9S8 nano-flower cluster array also can speed up the redox reaction based on the strong catalytic effect of the Co9S8 for LSBs [250,251]. Meanwhile, cobaltous selenide also have been used in LSBs. Song et al. prepared cobalt selenide (Co0.85Se) nanowire arrays as 3D conductive carbon layer as shown in Fig. 12(b) to modify the separator using the in-situ electrodeposition technique without any other modification for advanced LSBs [252]. The 3D conductive carbon layer containing CNT and acetylene black not only can be regarded as the strong support for Co0.85Se, but also can construct a hierarchical structure to effectively accelerate the fast electrons transfer. And the porous network structure of the modified layer also was conducive to accommodate the huge volume and electrolyte penetration. The nano-arrays can provide high specific surface area and ensure enough active sites for propelling the electrochemical reaction process of LSBs. Besides the application of single metal sulfide in separators materials of LSBs, bi-metallic sulfide materials also have been greatly improved the cell performance due to more defects engineering and enough active site, more excellent polarity characteristics, faster electron and Li+ transport channels than single metal sulfide [253–255]. For example, Yang et al. prepared the in situ-grown compressed NiCo2S4 barrier layer as presented in Fig. 12(c) to treat the cell separator for LSBs [256]. The porous NiCo2S4 nanosheet arrays were interconnected and conductive, which was facilitated for the diffusion and conduction of Li+ and can provide successive electrons transmission routes. The in-situ-grown NiCo2S4 nanosheet arrays formed as thin separator was intimately adhered to the separator. The mechanical compression treatment can form a dense NiCo2S4 thin membrane, which can suppress the diffusion and conduction pathways of LiPSs [257]. Meanwhile, the polar NiCo2S4 nanosheet arrays also can present strong chemical confinement and catalytic conversion toward LiPSs. In addition, some sulfates have been applied for LSBs. Zheng et al. fabricated the functional separators prepared via in-situ growth of hollow CoSO4 hydrate arrays as presented in Fig. 12(d) on pristine polypropylene membrane for LSBs [258]. The polar CoSO4 hydrate arrayed on PP membrane realized through vulcanizing the precursor based on its special structure can present more catalytically active sites for better confinement of LiPSs to reduce shuttling. More importantly, the catalytic activity of polar CoSO4 hydrate also can fasten the reciprocal conversion of LiPSs [259]. Especially, the unique hollow arrays of polar CoSO4 hydrate arrayed on the membrane presented relatively large specific surface area and high pore volume, which were helpful for accelerating liquid electrolyte wettability and confining more LiPSs. 4.1.4 Others For better explore an effective and cheap catalyst replacing noble metals, some metal nitrides have aroused wide interest due to long record in many catalytic applications. And different metal nitrides have appeared as enviably good electrocatalysts for electrocatalysis including oxidation-reduction of nitrogen. The excellent catalytic activity of metal nitrides usually has good electronic conductivity according to the range metallic materials, which is rather helpful for fast transfer of electrons during cycle. For example, Sun et al. fabricated an atomically dispersed supported metal catalyst with a Co–N4 structure on active carbon to modify separators of LSBs [260]. The Co-N-C catalyst based on the Co–N4 structure and special chemical bond can reduce the LiPSs shuttling through physical barrier and chemical affinity. More importantly, the composite has high specific surface area and many active sites, which was helpful for realizing the enhanced redox reaction of the sulfur species. Thus, the LSBs can realize the admirable cycle performance with a reversible discharge capacity with a low decay rate. Some electronically conducting polymers have outstanding electrical performance similar to metals and outstanding flexibility of organic polymers with easy processability. In addition, some electronically conducting polymers contain functional atoms which can absorb LiPSs, ensuring them widely used for LSBs. Meanwhile, researchers also combined electronically conducting polymers with various carbon materials or polar substances to obtain various composite materials, and the combining roles between these composite materials also brings the performance of LSBs more superior. Yamauchi et al. fabricated the double-layered separator included a macroporous polypropylene matrix layer and an arrayed poly(methyl methacrylate) microsphere retarding layer for LSBs [261]. The poly(methyl methacrylate) had excellent adsorption for the liquid electrolyte, which can greatly enhance the merit of the separator to maintain liquid electrolyte and brought admirable ionic conductivity. The ester groups in the PMMA had a strong chemical confinement effect on LiPSs. Meanwhile, the PMMA microspheres were easily self-assembled to obtain an array structure. All in all, under the dual effects of physical impediment and chemisorption, the separator modified by the PMMA microspheres can confine the diffusion and conduction of LiPSs. All in all, Table S2 presented various array structured materials of cell separators for further improving the cell performance, which will provide some valuable and admirable recommendations to compare the own merits and advancements in this aspect. According to these, it is believed multi-functional array structured materials will be better designed, fabricated and used for functional separators of LSBs. 4.2 Array structured materials for interlayers 4.2.1 Elemental metals Recently, some works have presented a hopeful way to enhance the electrochemical performance of the LSBs through the introduction of a functional cell interlayer. Although some interlayers have presented probability to reduce fast diffusion of LiPSs and enhance the cycle stability, some important problems still need to be resolved. Among numerous issues, some functional interlayers with poor electronic or lithium ion conductivity can produce smaller initial discharge capacity when compared to the corresponding cathode due to added resistance to a certain degree [262–266]. Thus some elemental metals are applied in interlayer of LSBs for addressing the above issues. Recently, Hu et al. fabricated the self-supporting titanium nanotube arrays interlayer as presented in Fig. 13 (a) for further improving the cell performance [267]. The mesh-like structure did not affect the cell conductivity of electrons and ions because it possessed enough available room for the liquid electrolyte and lithium species to make them transfer freely in the cell. Furthermore, the nanostructure including highly ordered 1D arrays also can provide available medium for anchoring LiPSs based on many Ti–O polar units. The outstanding performance can be realized for LSBs. From the above researching works, we can clearly see that there is still relatively little researching works in this area as a whole, and more works can be done in this area in the future. 4.2.2 Metal oxide As is known to all, metal oxides containing an anion of oxygen in the oxidation condition of oxygen anion generally have a strong polar surface, which the merit can significantly absorb and confine LiPSs. Compared to various carbon materials for example graphene, CNTs, carbon nanofibers, et al., metal oxides generally can provide enough polar active sites for strong confinement of LiPSs. Attributing to the own shortcomings and special band structures, many metal oxides even also have excellent conductivity, bringing significantly enhanced cell performance. As is known to all, metal oxide V2O5 is a layer-structured transition metal oxide, which the distinguishing features make V2O5 been widely applied in energy storage fields. Meanwhile, different V2O5 architectures have been applied in various batteries. Due to the strong catalytic effect and excellent adsorption with LiPSs for LSBs, V2O5 also have been applied for the LSBs. For example, Gao et al. fabricated 2D/1D V2O5 nanoplates arrays anchored carbon nanofiber networks acted as an effective cell interlayer for LSBs [268]. The introduction of the 2D/1D V2O5 nanoplates arrays grown carbon nanofiber interlayer can provide stable and fast electrons and ion pathways. The aligned V2O5 nanoplates on carbon nanofiber networks can provide a quasi-confined cushion room strongly anchoring and confining LiPSs. MnO2 is another transition metal oxide of the most widely studied and applied in various rechargeable secondary batteries including LSBs, which can effectively suppress the LiPSs with various crystallographic polymorphs through a chemical process. For example, Fan et al. prepared ultra-thin MnO2 sheet arrays anchored on the hollow carbon fibers as interlayers for LSBs [269]. The hollow structure of hollow carbon fibers can provide the convenience for the access of LiPSs with the MnO2 sheet arrays grown on both the inside and outside wall of hollow carbon fibers. The powerful chemical roles formed between MnO2 and LiPSs can suppress the LiPSs shuttling [270]. The ultra-thin MnO2 sheet arrayed anchored on hollow carbon fibers also can provide facilitated transmission channels of electrons and Li+ [271]. Finally, the LSBs with the functional interlayer can realize excellent electrochemical performance. Subsequently, Zhang et al. also prepared the carbonized cotton cloth decorated with MnO2 nanosheets as a multi-functional interlayer for LSBs [272]. The formed dense carbon cloth based materials can deliver a facilitated pathway for electron conduction and greatly relieve the huge volume change of electrode. The produced MnO2 also can produce the strong chemical bonding with LiPSs alike the mentioned above reason, which can effectively capture the LiPSs intermediates from the region of cell electrode and significantly be rather helpful for the recycle of active materials [273,274]. 4.2.3 Metal sulfide Nowadays, among various candidates of modified materials of interlayer, TMSs have obtained increasing interest. As main materials of interlayer for LSBs, TMSs have been applied to resolve problems of cycled LSBs. When compared with some carbon materials reducing soluble LiPSs shuttling according to physical confinement, TMSs generally own the excellent action with the LiPSs due to the strong polar interaction or Lewis acid base interaction combining the physical limitation. As everyone knows, the conductive cobalt sulfide cathode usually has some merits including outstanding specific discharge capacity and well long cycle performance when compared with the pure sulfur cathode. More importantly, the kind of metal sulfide also can fasten the surface-mediated redox reaction dynamic to lower the activation energy barrier and to improve the cell performance with the modified interlayers. For instance, Xie et al. reasonably fabricated a carbon cloth based self-standing interlayer included the Co4S3-embedded porous carbon nanoarrays based on a facile two-step method with cobalt-based metal-organic framework nanosheets as the template for LSBs [275]. The intertwined carbon networks and the polar Co4S3 nanoparticles in the prepared Co4S3/C@carbon cloth interlayer not only can reduce the LiPSs shuttling, but also can facilitate the lithium ion conduction [276]. Meanwhile, the enough interfaces between the polar Co4S3 nanoparticles and the conductive carbon substrate can be served as active sites to speed up the LiPSs transform and form the flower-like growth of Li2S, which finally mitigated the interlayer surface passivation and greatly enhanced the utilization rate of active materials [277,278]. MoS2, as a classic 2D layered disulfide, has been widely used in LSBs to work as a main material for battery interlayer due to its suitable polar feature with high-order LiPSs and facilitated diffusion of Li+ [279,280]. For example, Wang et al. prepared an ultra-thin and ultralight MoS2/carbon nanotube array as the cell interlayer of advanced LSBs as shown in Fig. 13(b and c) [281]. The formed CNT array membrane with outstanding electronic conductivity and excellent strength can give the assembled LSBs with even and facilitated conductive networks. The MoS2 nanosheets as a supporting skeleton also can provide a physical block to high-order LiPSs. More importantly, the strong chemical function and bonding based on the functional MoS2 nanosheets and high-order LiPSs also can be formed to reducing the LiPSs shuttling. More importantly, the produced self-discharge shortcomings combining the sulfur electrodes also can be dramatically suppressed based on the MoS2/CNT array interlayer [282–284]. The addition of the MoS2/CNT array interlayer can enhance the utilization rate of sulfur species and suppressed the LiPSs shuttling. As well known, Ni3S2 also usually present both strong LiPSs adsorption capability and excellent conductivity significantly enhancing the redox reaction of the adsorbed LiPSs, thus significantly improving the cell performance [285–287]. And metal disulfide Ni3S2 also has been applied in the interlayer of LSBs. For example, Tu et al. fabricated the single crystalline Ni3S2 nanowires covered with the N-doped carbon shell (NC) to produce the Ni3S2@NC core/shell arrays as presented in Fig. 13(d) by the chemical vapor deposition process including just one-step as the host of active materials [288]. The N-doped carbon shell can present good electronic conductivity which facilitated electron transportation and redox reaction. And the nanowire structure also can ensure the adaptability of huge volume expansion to maintain the structural stability of the electrode. Meanwhile, the NC shell can suppress the dissolution and diffusion of LiPSs combining the physical role and chemical confinement. While maintaining the strong catalytic activity, the anion vacancy (S2−) and unsaturated Zn centre in ZnS materials also can be regarded as an excellent Lewis acid to produce a coordinate bond with the LiPSs. More importantly, the kinetic analyses also indicate that the prepared ZnS not only can facilitate the redox reaction of LiPSs in liquid phase (Li2S8 → Li2S6 → Li2S4), but also can promote the good catalysis conversion of Li2S [289–291]. For example, Chen et al. fabricated the aligned sulfur-deficient ZnS1− x nanotube arrays deposited onto a self-supporting carbon cloth electrode as efficient catalyzer for LSBs as shown in Fig. 13(e) [292]. The efficient immobilization-diffusion on LiPSs can be obtained based on the combining role of structure construction ways and defect engineering of the ZnS1− x nanotube arrays. The sulfur-deficient structure also can be revealed according to a series of tests and characterizations, confirming the reasonable coordination condition and electronic structure can be formed which was rather helpful for fast transform among high-order LiPSs, low-order LiPSs and elemental sulfur. 4.2.4 MOFs Metal Organic Frameworks (MOFs) have become one of the most interest researching substances due to the controllable pore size, highly ordered structures and ultra-high porosity, which can provide a large number of merits for applying them in battery energy system. More importantly, many researchers also have thought of cooperating with MOFs with other functional substances to prepare some MOF composites, and their combining effects also bring more excellent performances. Meanwhile, MOF derivatives fabricated through applying some nanostructured MOF precursors can present better properties if reasonably applied in energy system can be obtained, which also can attract widespread attention. In the aspect of LSBs, MOFs with reasonable structure and large porosity can present more excellent performances when compared with other functional substances. Meanwhile, the MOF composites and MOF derivatives can absorb and confine LiPSs and loading elemental sulfur perfectly with enhanced electrical conductivity. In addition, some studies using MOF composites and MOF derivatives in LSBs as separators can obtain great progresses, which are mainly sourced from their excellent ionic selectivity and large surface area. More importantly, MOF derivatives also are ensured to be suitable substances for interlayers of LSBs due to extraordinary excellent electrochemical performance and can be acted as LiPSs block and the second current collectors [293–297]. For example, Wu et al. prepared an orderly arranged dual-role MIL-53(Al) nanorods array covered on carbon nanotube membrane obtained by the self-transformation of Al2O3 particle layer as functional interlayer as presented in Fig. 13(f) for LSBs [298]. The MIL-53(Al) nanorods array along with enough oxygen groups can build the uniform ion channels for homogenizing Li+ diffusion, thus ensuring steady Li plating and stripping behavior and suppressing the serious dendrite growth of metal Li. As a functional interlayer, the composite can work as a block to suppress LiPSs, which can be realized together based on the strong confinement and realize screening effect of the MOF nanorods array. Meanwhile, the composite with the array structure also can accelerate the redox reaction to enhance the availability of sulfur species. And the flexible carbon nanotube film can be acted as a self-supporting structure to adapt to metal Li and reduce the large volume change. All in all, Table S3 presented various array structured materials of cell interlayers for effectively improving the cell performance of the assembled LSBs, which will present many valuable suggestions to obtain the own merits and advancements in the aspect. According to these researches above-mentioned, the prepared multi-functional array structured materials will be better designed, fabricated and used in theinterlayers of LSBs. It is worth noting that the array structure also has some favorable factors for the lithium anode. When using the array structure as separator modified material on one side of anode, it affects the uniformity and stability of lithium deposition during the battery charging process. Well-designed array structures with complex spatial structures help promote the uniform distribution of lithium ions, prevent the formation of dendrites and dead lithium, maximize the reduction of active lithium loss during cycling, reduce capacity decay, and improve the overall lifespan of the battery. Additionally, the complex structure can effectively alleviate the risk of lithium dendrite penetration through the separator, thereby reducing the safety hazards of the battery. The array structure also enhances the stability of the electrode/electrolyte interface. A suitable array structure can provide a larger surface area, resulting in better contact and facilitating more efficient diffusion of lithium ions. Moreover, the array structure plays a role in maintaining the structural stability of the lithium metal anode. During the charge and discharge process, lithium metal undergoes volume changes, which lead to mechanical stress and deformation. Optimized array structures can accommodate these volume changes and minimize the strain on the lithium metal, thus mitigating these effects. In conclusion, the array structure in the lithium metal anode greatly influences its electrochemical performance, stability, and cycling characteristics. Future research should continue to explore the application of array structures in lithium anodes to further improve the efficiency and lifespan of lithium metal batteries. Carbon-based array structure materials generally exhibit excellent electrical conductivity. This characteristic helps facilitate the rapid transfer of electrons during the electrochemical processes of lithium-sulfur batteries, thereby enhancing overall battery performance. Carbon-based materials typically have a larger specific surface area and a complex spatial structure, providing sufficient space for sulfur deposition. This can increase the sulfur loading and the utilization of active sulfur species in Li-S batteries, ultimately improving their energy and power density. Carbon-based materials can also physically adsorb sulfur species, thereby limiting the shuttle effect of polysulfides in Li-S batteries and enhancing their cycling stability. Moreover, carbon-based materials possess high flexibility, making them suitable for structural design and modification. Furthermore, compared to other non-carbon-based materials, carbon-based materials are relatively abundant and cost-effective, making them more suitable for large-scale production and commercial applications. However, the limitation of carbon-based array structures on polysulfides is mainly due to physical adsorption, and the weak van der Waals forces-based interaction has limited effectiveness in restricting polysulfides. Hence, numerous researchers have undertaken efforts to resolve the limitations of carbon-based arrays by creating composite materials that possess both excellent conductivity and chemical adsorption ability. A substantial amount of research has been concentrated on the development of array structures of carbon composite materials with polar metal compounds and conductive polymers. Currently, extensive research is focused on the performance characteristics of various array structural materials, but there are some factors that cannot be ignored for practical applications, such as cost, manufacturing process complexity, and safety performance. (1) Carbon-based array structural materials, such as carbon nanotubes or graphene arrays, may be relatively expensive compared to other options. The fabrication process of pure carbon-based array materials is relatively simple but may involve high temperatures or chemical treatments. Carbon-based materials are generally considered safe, but their stability may be compromised during sulfur-based reactions in LSB, leading to capacity loss and safety concerns. (2) The cost of transition metal compounds@carbon materials (such as metal oxides or metal sulfides) varies depending on the specific materials used. The fabrication process of transition metal compounds may involve complex synthesis methods that require precise control of reaction parameters. Compared to carbon-based materials, the stability of certain transition metal compounds may be poorer, which can impact the overall safety of LSB. (3) Polymer@carbon materials offer cost-effectiveness compared to other alternatives, as they are often easy to obtain and process. Polymer materials can be fabricated using relatively simple methods such as solution casting or electrospinning. Polymer materials generally exhibit good stability and safety performance, making them suitable for LSB applications. 5 Challenges and strategies As is well known, array structured materials with many merits such as well-designed pore routes including hierarchical pores, stable structure skeletons, enough loading spaces, facilitated ion transport channels and so on can provide the prepared functional materials with low density, large surface area and enough loading mass of active materials. At present, array structured materials have gained significant attentions and are extensively utilized in various energy applications, particularly for LSBs. Firstly, they can effectively inhibit the aggregation of sulfur species. Additionally, they exhibit excellent adaptability to the substantial volume variations in electrode materials. Moreover, the structure also provides facilitated channels for electrons and Li+ transmission. Lastly, certain functional groups present in array-structured materials effectively adsorbing, confining and catalyzing performance among high-order/low-order LiPSs and elemental sulfur. 5.1 Novel synthesis methods for array structured materials As is known to all, although many array structured materials can be prepared and realized by using the above mentioned hydrothermal method, hot solvent way, chemical vapor deposition, electrodeposition method, template means and so on even in harsh environment, these preparation ways of array structured materials are usually prone to long-term synthesis time, many required resources supply, strict preparation environment or precise preparation instruments. All of these reasons can make the array structured materials be difficult in terms of rapid and large-scale production for applying them for LSBs. Additionally, in combination with other complementary structures and versatile materials, a wide range of array structured materials also can be developed, synthesized, and employed for the purpose of enhancing electrochemical performance and safety of LSBs. Hence, it is necessary to further optimize current methods for preparing array structured materials in LSBs, ensuring their maximum potential as modified electrodes or separators/interlayers materials. 5.2 Different designs including dimension and adsorption for array structured materials The added structures referring to different dimensions (zero, one, two or three dimension) together with the main array structured materials through combining their own merits also have been synthetized and applied for various energy storage and conversion systems including LSBs. When designing materials for array structured materials, we also should consider making the resulted material have excellent conduction ability of electrons and ions. Moreover, when preparing and implementing certain array structured materials in LSBs where lithium metal is used directly as the anode materials, it is essential for the modified cell separators or interlayers to take into careful consideration the issue of significant lithium dendrite formation. By doing so, the production of lithium dendrites during cycle can be suppressed, leading to an improvement in both the electrochemical performance and safety of LSBs. Meanwhile, when these designed and prepared array structured materials are used in LSBs, it firstly should consider to effectively suppress the LiPSs shuttling according to the thoughtful and admirable physical confinement. But, while researching LSBs, it has been discovered that achieving effective suppression of the dissolution and diffusion of LiPSs solely through physical confinement is challenging. Therefore, there is a need to find a robust chemical adsorption process that can synergistically enhance the inhibition of “shuttle effect” of LiPSs, alongside physical confinement. This is primarily because functionalized carbon materials are frequently employed in the structural design or modified materials of cathodes, separators or interlayers for LSBs. Furthermore, the reasonable control of the gap size between each array, as well as the specifications and dimensions of the arrays themselves, the physical and chemical properties of the prepared materials, and the electrochemical performance of the obtained electrodes and separators/interlayers are all crucial for array structured materials. However, carbon materials are generally non-polar materials, so they are rather difficult to form a strong adsorption effect on polar LiPSs. In this way, it is generally necessary to use strong polar functional materials to modify carbon materials with other special structures, which can reduce the dissolution and diffusion of LiPSs in liquid electrolyte. This result can ultimately effectively improve the applied rate of elemental sulfur in the assembled batteries, thereby achieving high electrochemical and safety performance of LSBs. The performance of batteries under high current density is crucial for the practical application of LSBs. Maintaining structural integrity of array structural materials is paramount when used as LSB electrodes even under high current density. Thus, several strategies have been explored to enhance structural integrity while preserving good electrochemical properties. (1) The design of electrode structure plays a vital role in maintaining structural integrity under high current density. Implementing layered or interconnected structures with appropriate pore distribution helps ensure uniform current distribution and minimizes localized high current density areas which may cause structural degradation.
