Increasing the mechanical robustness of the array structure can be achieved by reducing inter-unit spacing, deepening the embedding of the array structure in the substrate, and utilizing dual substrates to create a “sandwiched” configuration. (2) The selection of materials with exceptional mechanical properties is paramount. Array structural materials such as carbon nanotubes, graphene or conductive polymers with high mechanical strength can significantly enhance structural stability and prevent deformation or fracture of the electrode at high current densities. (3) Additionally, employing binders with excellent adhesion to both the active material and current collector is crucial. Utilizing conductive binders with excellent mechanical strength enhances the stability of the electrode during electrochemical cycling. Due to its unique advantages, the array structure may exhibit variations in electrochemical performance when used as independent electrodes. Firstly, independent electrodes facilitate direct contact between the active material and electrolyte, potentially leading to improved specific capacity, rate capability and overall electrochemical performance. Secondly, independent electrodes lack additional current collectors, reducing charge transfer resistance. However, this absence may disperse the current generated by the active material, leading to insufficient convergence of large currents and potentially unstable current output. Independent electrodes may also encounter challenges in maintaining structural stability. 5.3 Various catalysts for array structured materials As everyone is aware, recently, various types of catalysts have been extensively applied to electrodes or separators/interlayers of LSBs. This has significantly improved catalytic efficiency and continuously advanced the catalytic direction from a single discharge catalytic direction to a bidirectional catalytic direction. The application of these novel multi-functional catalysts based on array structured composite materials has further elevated the electrochemical performance of LSBs However, there have been very few published papers on the widespread utilization of array structured materials for solid-state LSBs with slower reaction kinetics, which is rather important area of future development towards achieving both high energy density and exceptional safety of LSBs including solid-state LSBs. Additionally, there are still some issues and drawbacks pertaining to the wide application of array structured materials for LSBs. Considering these factors, it is highly significant to introduce additional structural designs, modifications, or collaborative joint modifications with multifunctional catalysts to array structured materials between different battery components. This will serve to further enhance the electrochemical performance and safety of LSBs in the future. 5.4 Balance some factors and performance of array structured materials for LSBs As we all know, the aim of the design, preparation and application about array structured materials for LSBs is to endow the assembled cells with more energy density and safety for satisfying the growing demands for high energy storage and conversion systems in actual application. However, just as most products encounter numerous difficulties from small to medium-sized experiments even to large-scale preparation, it is becoming increasingly important to balance the amount of chemical performance improvement brought by the array structured materials to the battery with the additional cost. This phenomenon or irreducible embarrassment seems to be reflected not only in array structured materials, but also in the selection of material composition or corresponding structure of applied materials for more electrodes or separators/interlayers in the future. Nowadays, we also hope that there are more researchers to pay much attention for better designing and preparing additional array structured materials, which can greatly enhance the electrochemical performance and safety of LSBs under the premise of ensuring low preparation cost, simple and operable processes and the strong ability to produce and prepare even in large quantities. All in all, based on the preliminary explorations, different kinds of initial materials can be elaborately designed and applied to the preparation of array structured materials which mainly include array structured carbon materials, array structured metal@carbon materials, array structured metal oxide, array structured metal sulfide@carbon materials, array structured metal nitride@carbon materials, array structured metal phosphide@carbon materials, array structured electronically conducting polymer@carbon materials and so on. For improving the electrochemical performance of LSBs, various functional materials have been utilized for separators and interlayers. These materials mainly include elemental metals, carbon materials, modified carbon materials, metal oxides, metal sulfides, MOFs and so on. It is rather important to consider the cost when selecting the material precursor for array structured materials. Additionally, the ease of the synthesis process and its potential to enhance performance should also be taken into account. The key principle in the design and preparation of array structured materials is to establish a clear relationship which can maintain the existence and stability of the active materials. Furthermore, when aiming to enhance the physicochemical performances of array structured materials by additional structures or modified materials, the continuity of the processes should also be considered. 5.5 Problems and corresponding solutions of array structured materials for LSBs Although the functional materials based on array structure has realized relatively well results when they are applied in LSBs, some shortcomings and drawbacks until now as following still exist. (1) In the synthesis process of some array structured materials for LSBs, it can still need some strong acids or alkali, which will lead to it easy to etch the manufactured equipment, and some solvents applied in the synthesis process of array structured materials may have some harm to people to a certain extent. All of these make green preparation methods of array structured materials become very important. (2) It is rather difficult for the reasonable and accurately controlling of the gap size between each array, and the specifications and dimensions of the array itself. The gap between the sub-units in the array structured material can greatly buffer the huge volume expansion during the cycle of electrode materials, thus reducing the electrode structure from serious collapse and releasing the accumulation of stress and strain preventing the material from cracking like the traditional compact film. However, too large gap will lead to its inability to inhibit “shuttle effect” of LiPSs through the strong physical limitation of LiPSs, and even if it is modified later, its performance will not be improved. (3) When compared with current designs of some special structures for functional materials of LSBs, the overall morphologies of array structured materials are still relatively single. For example, there is an important researching trend to obtain the 3D array structured materials, which can endow this kind of structural materials more functionalities such as larger specific surface area, superior mechanical properties and convenient channels for Li+ transport. Generally, array structured materials still exist some shortcomings which still need endow more enhancement for further improving the electrochemical performance and safety of LSBs in the future. Meanwhile, it is also rather vital to elucidate the preparation and formation of array structure during the preparation process of array structured materials. The controllable construction of the shape, gap and size of array structure materials play a crucial role in achieving high-performance functional materials with array structures. In summary, the presence of gaps between sub-units in array-structured materials can effectively mitigate the large volume expansion during cycle, thus preventing significant collapse of the electrode structure. Moreover, these sub-units can be further designed and prepared as composite array electrodes with multi-functional or multi-stage structures, allowing the advantageous properties of each component to synergistically enhance electrochemical performance of electrodes or separators/interlayers in LSBs. The functional materials of array structured materials can not only be designed and prepared with reasonable gap to reduce the “shuttle effect” of LiPSs through the physical confinement, but also be convenient for functional materials modification to adsorb LiPSs in the chemical form and catalyze the conversion between LiPSs and elemental sulfur, which will effectively suppress the “shuttle effect” of LiPSs, enhancing the electrochemical performance and safety of LSBs to a certain extent. 6 Conclusions and prospects 6.1 Problems and corresponding solutions of array structured materials for LSBs In this study, some viewpoints and suggestions about the array structured materials used in LSBs according to various preparation ways, morphology design and their corresponding categories, working mechanisms of array structured materials for further improving electrochemical performances and enhancing high safety are generalized and evaluated. In addition, we also have many elaborate description and explanation for the application of array structured materials in high performance LSBs and construct the structure-activity connection between array structured materials and the electrochemical performance and safety of the assembled LSBs using the array structured materials. Finally, the available problems, challenges and some reasonable suggestions about their preparations, modifications and practical use of array structured materials in LSBs are also put forward and overviewed. For LSBs, we also need reasonably select some functional materials from their detailed components based on different physicochemical performance of various materials besides considering array structured materials. In addition to efficiently conducting the array structure to achieve high performance for LSBs, it is crucial to consider the rational selection of initial materials, synthesis methods and resulting products, as well as other supplementary structures in combination with the formed array structure. Analyzing the influence of array-structured materials on battery performance in isolation can yield significant insights. Therefore, it is imperative to thoroughly review and take into account recommendations and guidance pertaining to the design and preparation of array-structured materials for LSBs. Moreover, considering the physical and chemical properties of array-structured materials and their working environment is essential in order to enable the versatile use of multifunctional array-structured materials in LSBs. In summary, a comprehensive examination of researching related to the physical and chemical performances, as well as material science aspects of structural designs, is necessary to significantly enhance the electrochemical performance and safety of array-structured materials for LSBs. All in all, the selection of materials and structure designs of array structure are rather important for LSBs. Thus, different application of materials and various structure designs have also been the important effecting elements on the performances of the materials with array structures for LSBs. (1) For the aspect of size dimension, it is necessary to reasonably control the array structure more accurately including their gaps. Meanwhile, in the aspect of macro length scale, it also should be considered to combine with some functional conducting materials, thus enhancing the conductivity of the composite materials combining array structured materials. Of course, some in-situ ways for array structured materials also can be composited with some materials with other outstanding performances, which also is rather helpful for fast electron conduction during cell cycle. (2) Further enhancement of the channels and conduction ability of charge and ion transfer can be achieved by considering the inclusion of supplementary structures in array-structured materials. These other additional composite materials with new and additional structures not only have excellent conductivity for electrons and ions, but also require to be able to form different array structured materials to further enrich their functions. (3) More diverse morphological structures should be considered in future researches on array structured materials for LSBs. Although the general form of array structured materials is relatively simple which is helpful for large-scale preparation process of array structured materials, their functionality still needs to be improved. And although array structured materials with complex forms have complete functions, their large-scale production and preparation will present difficult to a certain extent. 6.2 Priority suggestions of array structured materials for LSBs Array structured materials have realized some progresses and developments in LSBs, but there are some thorny issues still need to be urgently addressed. These issues will pose a serious threat to the commercialization process of array structured materials in LSBs Thus we should seriously pay enough attention to the following viewpoints and recommendations for wide application of array structured materials in LSBs shown in Fig. 14 as following. (1) Firstly, we should pay enough attention for reasonably choosing raw materials based on the principles and obtain relative balance based on preparation cost and processes, important requirements, applied compositions (electrodes, separators and interlayers) of LSBs about these array structured materials. We also need consider to make the prepared array structured materials be well matched with additional modifications for effectively enhancing the electrochemical performances and safety of LSBs. During the selection and preparation of array structured materials, there are many factors affecting their physical and chemical properties, which require us to use the single factor control variates method to explore the main factors. (2) Further researches on the relationship between the electrochemical performance and safety of cells, as well as the physical and chemical properties of array-structured materials, can improve cell performance while reducing preparation costs. Additionally, it is crucial to investigate the formation mechanism and working mechanism of array-structured materials in assembled LSBs. These studies will establish a strong foundation for the practical application and commercialization of array structured materials in LSBs. (3) Besides the micro-structure design of array structured materials for LSBs, we also should consider to design and prepare the reasonable macro-structure of array structured materials for further enhancing their electrochemical performances and safety of LSBs. For example, macro 3D array structured materials can present larger specific surface area, higher mechanical properties, and more convenient channels for lithium ions transport than that of some materials from other dimensional macro materials. Meanwhile, in the design processes of the array structure, we should also consider how to ensure the uniform distribution of the additional modified materials within the array structured materials during the subsequent treatment. This will further enhance the electrochemical performance of the battery. It is also crucial to construct array structured materials with appropriate specific surface area, pore size and distribution, as well as array gap, in order to achieve high performance for LSBs. Finally, the designs and synthesis of pore structures and array layout for the applied materials in high performance LSBs can be achieved. (4) According to advanced test devices for the innovation of materials and structure-activity relationship of array structured materials, researchers still need to continuously adjust the preparation processes and develop novel methods for preparing array structured materials to further improve the electrochemical and safety performances of LSBs. In the current methods of preparing array structured materials, there are some problems, such as demanding conditions, long preparation processes, high energy consumption, significant environmental pollution, or difficulty in ensuring the uniformity of the products prepared during large-scale production. These issues will pose serious obstacles to the commercial application of array structured materials in LSBs. Based on the above issues, we still need to consider integrating these methods or combine them with other process flows for further optimizing the performance of array structured materials, ultimately achieving a dual harvest of electrochemical performance and safety of LSBs. Overall, the preparation methods of more novel array structured materials still need to be highly valued by researchers, ultimately enabling the prepared array structured materials to have reasonable gaps, array distribution, specific surface area and pore volume and so on. This will enable the assembled LSBs to exhibit optimal electrochemical performance and excellent safety. (5) On the application aspect of array structured materials for LSBs, array structured materials cannot be used solely in a single component of LSBs, the application of such materials can also be expanded to include multiple combinations of electrodes, interlayers or separators in the battery. All of these outcomes have the potential to yield unexpected and remarkable results. Meanwhile, we also should consider whether materials with some harsh environments such as high and low temperature resistance at the same time can be applied in array structured materials, so as to exert their synergistic effects and significantly improve the electrochemical and safety of LSBs. In addition to liquid LSBs, we should also continuously explore the application prospects of multi-functional array structured materials in solid-state LSBs, in the hope of further improving the safety of such batteries. However, as of now, there is relatively little researches on the simultaneous application of array structured materials to cell electrodes, separators or interlayers of LSBs. This may be a promising researching direction for the future application of materials with this structure in LSBs. (6) Currently, through conducting various conventional tests prior to and post battery cycling, we can gather substantial information regarding the influence of the physicochemical properties of array-structured materials on the performance of LSBs. However, these testing processes cannot evaluate or obtain the impact of various material components, phases and mechanisms of action formed by materials with this structure throughout the entire charging and discharging process on battery performances. As is well known, the development and updating of many testing equipment are based on the establishment and solution of certain theoretical models. Therefore, we still need to further explore the formation mechanism of this structure and the working mechanisms of the materials used in this structure on battery performance. Based on the researches of these theories, we also need to continuously develop novel testing methods for better obtaining the impact of materials with this structure on battery performance online or in-situ forms. It is gratifying that some in-situ testing methods such as in situ Raman, XRD, FTIR, etc. have been developed and applied in LSBs. These methods allow for continuous monitoring of the entire reaction process in LSBs during charging and discharging processes, enabling us to improve the utilization of array structured materials in LSBs. This progress will lay a solid foundation for the widespread application of LSBs utilizing these materials. However, the current in-situ testing equipment remains insufficient for the researches on array structured materials in LSBs. The integration of in-situ testing methods can offer numerous benefits for exploring materials with such structures in LSBs. (7) According to the sophisticated developments of software and theoretical simulation calculation, an advanced and generalized database involving in structure-activity relationship of array structured materials with electrochemical performance can be formed and applied in the actual LSBs. According to the corresponding theoretical calculation including density functional theory (DFT) and ab initio or AI molecular dynamics simulation, the initial and detailed evaluation of the electrochemical performance and safety of LSBs can be realized using the corresponding analog computations. Based on the above elaboration and studies on the preparation ways of array structured materials, their composition mechanisms, structure-activity relationship and working mechanisms of the array structured materials for high performance LSBs, some related multifunctional materials with the designed array structure also can be stretched to other secondary batteries. The review may pave a spacious avenue for the novel array structured materials applied other energy storage and conversion systems. Thus, we strongly convince that with the fast development and continued progresses of novel preparation ways, some advanced manufacturing or testing equipment, the synthesis of multi-functional array structured materials combining other modifications will be more facilitated, and the merits may endow more chances for fast development and accelerating the commercialization of LSBs even other secondary batteries. Nanping Deng is associate professor and doctoral supervisor of the School of Textile Science and Engineering, Tiangong University. He is mainly engaged in the preparation of nanofiber materials and its application in the field of energy system including various secondary cells and functional electrocatalysts. He has published 60 SCI papers as the first and corresponding author in ESM, AFM, Small, JEC and other journals, including 40 SCI papers in the first region, 25 papers with an impact factor greater than 10, and 4 papers were selected as ESI highly cited papers, with a total number of citations up to 3370 times and an h-index of 34. His doctoral thesis won the excellent doctoral thesis of China Textile Engineering Society and Tianjin Excellent doctoral thesis, and won the “Wang Shanyuan Excellent doctoral Fund”. Granted 10 patents, in 2021∼2023 for three consecutive years in the “top 2% of the world's top scientists list”. Xiaofan Feng received her Bachelor’s degree in Textile Engineering, Qingdao University, China in 2022. Now, she is studying for a master's degree at Tiangong University. Her research mainly concentrates on electrospun materials for lithium-sulfur batteries and lithium-ion batteries. Yongbing Jin received his Bachelor’s degree in Nonwoven Materials and Engineering from Tiangong University in 2022. He is currently pursuing a Master’s degree at Tiangong University. His research focuses on the modification of cathode materials and separators for high-performance lithium-sulfur batteries. His current main research direction involves utilizing electrospinning technology to prepare modified materials and applying them in lithium-sulfur batteries. Zhaozhao Peng received his Bachelor's degree in Textile Science and Engineering from Tiangong University. Now, he is pursuing his master's degree at Tiangong University. He has been engaged in the functional design and performance research of electrolyte separators for lithium batteries for a long time. His current main research content is the preparation of functional nanofibers using electrospinning and electrostatic blowing techniques, and their application as electrolyte separators in lithium batteries. Yang Feng received his M.S. degree in 2021 from the School of Textile Science and Engineering at Tiangong University, Tianjin, China. Currently, he is a Ph.D. student in Prof. Kai Zhang’s group with the College of Chemistry at Nankai University, Tianjin, China. His current research focuses on synthesis and characterization of advanced materials for high energy lithium-based batteries. Ying Tian now studying in Tiangong University as an undergraduate. She is majoring in nonwovens and engineering, and she mainly involved in the research of lithium battery separator and some literature reading in the laboratory. Yong Liu received his Ph.D. degree of Textile Materials and Design from Donghua University, Shanghai, China, in 2008. Heis a full professor in the School of Textile Science and Engineering in Tiangong University, China. During 2015-2016, he was a visiting scholar at Cornell University in USA. His research interests focus on advanced fiber materials, nanocomposites, smart textiles and their applications on energy, environment, etc. He has published more than 100 peer-reviewed journal papers, conference proceedings. He has also published 6 books with co-authors. Lu Gao joined in the School of Textile Science and Engineering, Tiangong University, in July, 2022. She received her PhD degree in June, 2022 from Tiangong University. Her current research is mainly focused on the ultrafine nanofiber based high performance batteries, especially all-solid-state lithium metal batteries and sodium metal batteries. Weimin Kang has been working in Tiangong University, China since 2007, and obtained his doctoral degree in textile chemical engineering from Tiangong University in 2012. He was appointed to professor in 2017. His scientific interests are the design, preparation and evaluation of novel nanofibers and their application in storage areas such as fuel cells. He won the national textile youth science and technology innovation leader, the first-level talent of Tianjin “131” innovative talent training project, and won the 2018 Textile Youth Science and Technology Award and Baicao Fiber Textile Technology Achievement Transformation Promotion Award. And he was named into the World's Top 2% Scientists 2021. Bowen Cheng received his doctoral degree in Chemical Engineering from Tiangong University, China in 2003, and studied in Hochschule Niederrhein, Germany as a doctoral exchange student in 2001. Then he was appointed as a research associate at the University of Leeds, England. His research focuses on novel fiber materials, advanced functional nonwovens and smart textiles for energy harvesting and storage.

coredata.dc:description: Lithium-sulfur battery (LSB) has brought much attention and concern because of high theoretical specific capacity and energy density as one of main competitors for next-generation energy storage systems. The widely commercial application and development of LSB is mainly hindered by serious “shuttle effect” of lithium polysulfides (LiPSs), slow reaction kinetics, notorious lithium dendrites, etc. In various structures of LSB materials, array structured materials, possessing the composition of ordered micro units with the same or similar characteristics of each unit, present excellent application potential for various secondary cells due to some merits such as immobilization of active substances, high specific surface area, appropriate pore sizes, easy modification of functional material surface, accommodated huge volume change, enough facilitated transportation for electrons/lithium ions, and special functional groups strongly adsorbing LiPSs. Thus many novel array structured materials are applied to battery for tackling thorny problems mentioned above. In this review, recent progresses and developments on array structured materials applied in LSBs including preparation ways, collaborative structural designs based on array structures, and action mechanism analyses in improving electrochemical performance and safety are summarized. Meanwhile, we also have detailed discussion for array structured materials in LSBs and constructed the structure-function relationships between array structured materials and battery performances. Lastly, some directions and prospects about preparation ways, functional modifications, and practical applications of array structured materials in LSBs are generalized. We hope the review can attract more researchers' attention and bring more studying on array structured materials for other secondary batteries including LSB.
